An 82-year-old woman is brought to the clinic by her caregiver for a new leg wound. The patient has had chronic lower-extremity swelling for many years. Over the past 2 weeks, she developed a small, shallow opening on her right anterior lower leg that has slowly expanded. She has no fever, chills, warmth, or purulent drainage. The patient says that her legs often feel tired and heavy, especially when sitting for extended periods, but they improve with walking.

Her past medical history includes hypertension, degenerative joint disease, and obesity.

Vital sign signs normal. Cardiovascular examination shows normal rate and rhythm and no murmurs. Estimated jugular venous pressure is normal. The patient's lungs are clear. Lower extremities have symmetric edema bilaterally; the wound is shown in the image below. The feet are warm with palpable dorsalis pedis pulses bilaterally.

In addition to wound dressing recommendations, what is the best next step in management of this patient?
explanation:
This patient has lower-extremity ulceration from chronic venous insufficiency (CVI). Symptoms of CVI are variable, but characteristic findings include aching or heavy pain in the legs, visible varicosities, chronic edema, and brawny discoloration of the lower legs. Risk factors include smoking, prior thromboembolic disease, older age, family history, and obesity. Prior ulceration is a strong predictor of future recurrence. First-line treatment for CVI should include lower-extremity elevation (at least 20-30 minutes 3 or 4 times a day), leg exercise, weight loss, and continuous compressive therapy. Prescription graduated compression stockings increase healing, with improvement rates up to 97% in compliant patients. This is thought to be due to improved venous hemodynamics, optimized fibrinolysis, and reduction of inflammation. Contraindications include moderate-to-severe peripheral arterial disease or active cellulitis. Aspirin therapy also has been shown to accelerate the ulcer healing process and is recommended.

(Choice A) Ankle brachial indices are an effective screening assessment for patients with symptomatic peripheral arterial disease (PAD). Features suggesting PAD include nonpalpable pulses, claudication, or rest pain. This patient's improvement with walking is not consistent with PAD.

(Choice C) Furosemide and other diuretics have no role in the treatment of lower-extremity edema due to CVI. A thorough physical examination should be performed to exclude other potential etiologies such as heart failure, for which this treatment would be indicated.

(Choice D) This patient's skin changes are most consistent with chronic venous stasis dermatitis with ulceration rather than an acute cellulitis or wound infection. As a result, treatment with either oral or topical antibiotics is not warranted. Findings suggesting superimposed cellulitis include a sudden increase in pain or erythema, fever, leukocytosis, or significant warmth on palpation.

(Choice E) Supplementation with oral zinc sulfate has been proposed for the treatment of arterial and venous lower-extremity ulcers, but trials to date have found no significant beneficial effect.

Educational objective:
Management of chronic venous insufficiency (with or without ulceration) consists of lower-extremity elevation, leg exercise, weight loss, and continuous compressive therapy. Aspirin accelerates ulcer healing. Topical antibiotics, zinc sulfate, and hyperbaric oxygen therapy are not effective.

A 56-year-old woman who is post-operative day #1 after a laparoscopic cholecystectomy complains of chest discomfort. The patient reports that in the early hours of the morning, she was awakened from sleep with nausea, one episode of vomiting, and persistent burning in her chest. Her only medical history includes hypertension, which has been well-controlled with medication. Her other current medications include ondansetron, acetaminophen, and hydrocodone.

Her temperature is 37.9 C (100.2,F), blood pressure is 92/60 mm Hg, heart rate is 90/min, and respirations are 18/min. Her BMI is 31 kg/m². She is in moderate distress and appears anxious. There is no murmur on cardiac examination and bilateral fine crackles are heard at the lung bases. Her abdomen is distended and non-tender with an incision that is clean and intact. Bowel sounds are diminished. There is no rebound tenderness or rigidity. There is no peripheral edema. A 12 lead EKG is performed and displayed below:

Which of the following would be the most appropriate next step in managing this patient?
choice_b: CT scan of the chest with contrast
explanation:
This patient is having a perioperative ST elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). The electrocardiogram is diagnostic and shows up to 5 mm of convex ST elevation in the anterior precordial and lateral limb leads along with characteristic reciprocal changes of ST depression in the inferior leads, suggestive of an occlusive thrombus in the left anterior descending artery (LAD). Current guidelines recommend that patients with STEMI undergo emergent reperfusion (preferably by angioplasty and stent, if available) without any delays in treatment. While being prepared for transport to the cardiac cath lab, patients should receive aspirin 325 mg (as 4 aspirin 81 mg chewed), unfractionated heparin, and a beta blocker (in the absence of contraindications). At cardiac cath, this patient did have an LAD thrombus which was removed and stented. A post-procedure EKG shows near resolution of the EKG changes.

(Choice B) The postoperative chest pain and diagnostic 12 lead EKG are highly suggestive of a cardiac etiology rather than a pulmonary embolism in this patient.

(Choice C) Although beta blockers are generally indicated in acute coronary syndromes, this patient has an abnormally low blood pressure in the setting of a known history of hypertension, and should not acutely receive an intravenous beta blocker that could further lower her blood pressure.

(Choice D) Although morphine is a reasonable option for pain control while awaiting reperfusion, there is no role for pantoprazole in this patient.

(Choice E) Transthoracic echocardiogram could be useful to evaluate for acute valvular lesions, CHF, or sometimes a questionable diagnosis of acute coronary syndrome (i.e., non-diagnostic EKG). However, this patient has a diagnostic EKG for acute coronary syndrome and no murmur on exam to suggest valvular disease.

Educational objective:
Patients with STEMI should undergo prompt and emergent evaluation with cardiac catheterization (preferably with angioplasty and stent) and receive concurrent medical therapy with aspirin, heparin, and a beta blocker (if no contraindications exist).

stem: A 69-year-old man with a history of coronary artery disease comes to the office with chest pain on moderate exertion. Over the last year, he has experienced pressure-like chest pain when walking at a fast pace or climbing stairs. He thinks this affects his quality of life as he has to stop to rest and take sublingual nitroglycerin each time. The patient has no shortness of breath, lightheadedness, syncope, or lower extremity swelling. He underwent coronary artery bypass surgery 8 years ago and has had 2 percutaneous coronary interventions over the last 2 years. Current medications include metoprolol succinate, amlodipine, lisinopril, extended-release isosorbide mononitrate, aspirin, clopidogrel, high-intensity rosuvastatin, and sublingual nitroglycerin as needed. He stopped smoking 10 years ago and does not drink alcohol. Blood pressure is 105/65 mm Hg and pulse is 55/min. The lungs are clear on auscultation. ECG shows normal sinus rhythm with T-wave inversion in leads III and aVF and a QTc interval of 410 msec. His last serum creatinine was 0.8 mg/dL and LDL cholesterol level was 68 mg/dL. Echocardiogram shows apical hypokinesis with left ventricular ejection fraction of 55%. Myocardial perfusion imaging reveals moderate ischemia of the inferior wall. Coronary angiography shows no intervenable lesions. Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient's symptoms?
choice_e: Increase isosorbide mononitrate to twice daily
explanation:
This patient continues to have activity-limiting chronic stable angina despite optimal medical therapy and coronary revascularization. When initial treatment is unsuccessful in relieving anginal symptoms, the addition of ranolazine may be used as a substitute for or in combination with beta blockers and other antianginal therapies. Ranolazine is a late sodium channel blocker that causes decreased influx of calcium into cardiomyocytes, resulting in lower ventricular wall tension and reduced myocardial oxygen consumption. This drug has the advantage of decreasing the frequency and severity of anginal symptoms and improving overall exercise capacity without significantly affecting heart rate or blood pressure. However, ranolazine has not been shown to improve other cardiovascular outcomes, including mortality and incidence of myocardial infarction.

(Choice A) This patient is already taking a calcium channel blocker (amlodipine), and the addition of another agent from a similar class (eg, diltiazem, verapamil, felodipine) is not indicated.

(Choice C) Although ACE inhibitors and angiotensin-receptor blockers reduce myocardial oxygen consumption by decreasing afterload, their overall effect on improving anginal pain is small. Furthermore, the addition of an angiotensin receptor blocker (eg, valsartan) to an ACE inhibitor (eg, lisinopril) is not typically recommended due to limited additional benefit and risk of side effects (eg, hyperkalemia, hypotension).

(Choice D) Beta blockers are the preferred first-line therapy for patients with stable angina because beta blockers, unlike calcium channel blockers, improve long-term survival in patients with prior myocardial infarction or left ventricular systolic dysfunction. Discontinuing metoprolol and starting diltiazem is not indicated in the absence of beta blocker intolerance.

(Choice E) Long-acting nitrates (eg, isosorbide mononitrate) are effective in improving chronic stable angina symptoms; however, long-term use is limited by the development of nitrate tolerance. Extended-release isosorbide mononitrate is typically dosed once daily; increasing to twice daily is unlikely to provide significant benefit.

Educational objective:
Ranolazine decreases myocardial oxygen consumption and provides effective treatment for chronic stable angina without significantly affecting heart rate or blood pressure. It may be used as a substitute for or in combination with beta blockers and other antianginal therapies when initial treatment is unsuccessful in relieving chronic stable angina.

stem: A 78-year-old woman comes to the physician following discharge from the hospital. One week ago, she had gone to the emergency department for palpitations, which she had experienced several times before, and she was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. The arrhythmia resolved spontaneously overnight, and the patient was discharged the following day. She has no chest pain or shortness of breath and has never had syncope. Past medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia. The patient's medications include aspirin, diltiazem, atorvastatin, and ramipril. She exercises most days of the week on a stationary bicycle for 20-30 minutes without any difficulty. The patient volunteers at a senior center and helps care for her husband with Alzheimer's dementia. Blood pressure is 135/75 mm Hg. pulse is 75 and regular, and BMI is 25 kg/m². Cardiac auscultation shows no murmurs. Her lungs are clear. Distal pulses are normal and symmetric. There is no edema. Electrocardiogram (ECG) shows normal sinus rhythm with no significant repolarization abnormalities. Transthoracic echocardiogram shows a mildly dilated left atrium, left ventricular ejection fraction of 55%. and mild mitral and tricuspid regurgitation. Laboratory studies show a TSH of 2.9 μU/mL. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
explanation:
This patient presented with paroxysmal atrial fibrillation (AF) that has spontaneously converted to sinus rhythm. Systemic thromboembolism is a major cause of long-term morbidity in patients with AF. Treatment with warfarin or target-specific oral anticoagulants has been shown to significantly reduce the risk of embolization in patients at moderate to high risk for thromboembolic events. Recent guidelines have recommended the use of a modified CHA2DS2-VASc score for stroke risk assessment in patients with nonvalvular AF. This patient has a CHA2DS2-VASc score of 4 (female gender, age >75, and hypertension) and should be managed with anticoagulation to reduce the long-term risk of systemic embolization.

(Choice A) Amiodarone is occasionally used for maintenance of sinus rhythm in patients with recurrent, symptomatic AF (rhythm-control strategy). This patient has spontaneously converted to sinus rhythm, and current evidence suggests no significant difference in the risk of systemic thromboembolism between the rate- and rhythm-control strategies.

(Choice C) Beta blockers and/or calcium channel blockers are used for heart rate control in patients with persistent AF. This patient has converted to sinus rhythm and would not benefit from additional beta blocker therapy.

(Choice D) An exercise stress test is used primarily to evaluate for coronary artery disease (CAD) in patients with suspicious symptoms. It is occasionally used to assess rate control in AF patients with exertional symptoms. But this patient is now asymptomatic and stress testing is not indicated.

(Choice E) Transesophageal echocardiography is performed to evaluate for intracardiac thrombus (left atrium or left atrial appendage thrombus) in patients with AF who have not been adequately anticoagulated prior to cardioversion. It has no role in patients with paroxysmal AF who are in sinus rhythm.

Educational objective:
Warfarin or target-specific oral anticoagulants have been shown to significantly reduce the risk of embolization in patients with atrial fibrillation and moderate to high risk for thromboembolic events. The CHA2DS2-VASc score is recommended for assessment of stroke risk in patients with nonvalvular atrial fibrillation.

A 69-year-old woman comes to the physician with right calf pain when walking. The pain has been present for several months but is now starting to limit her daily walks and shopping. It is described as a deep ache or cramp. The pain initially occurred after the patient walked 6 blocks, but now occurs after 2 blocks. It dissipates rapidly with rest. She has no chest pain or leg edema. The patient has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diet-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus, and cigarette use. She has reduced her smoking to about 10 cigarettes a day. Her medications include simvastatin, ramipril, aspirin, calcium, and vitamin D.

The patient's blood pressure is 128/77 mm Hg and pulse is 72/min. Cardiac, lung, and abdominal examinations are unremarkable. Her femoral pulses are 2+ and symmetrical. Popliteal and dorsalis pedis pulses on the right feel diminished relative to the left. Her ankle-brachial index is 0.7 on the right and 0.9 on the left. Electrocardiogram shows normal sinus rhythm and non-specific ST-segment and T-wave changes. After smoking cessation, aggressive risk factor modification, and a supervised incremental walking program, which of the following would be the best next step in management if life-style-limiting claudication persists?
explanation:
This patient has claudication suggestive of peripheral artery disease (PAD). Modifying risk factors (especially smoking cessation) and adding graded exercise therapy can improve symptoms and decrease the progression of disease. In addition to these lifestyle changes, medical therapy is a reasonable option in most patients. Antiplatelet therapy is the preferred initial therapy for PAD, and aspirin is the preferred drug due to cost and efficacy. Clopidogrel is typically used in patients who cannot tolerate aspirin. Patients who are still symptomatic on antiplatelet therapy require second-line agents such as cilostazol, a phosphodiesterase inhibitor and vasodilator that inhibits platelet aggregation and significantly increases maximal and pain-free walking distances. Cilostazol is normally used in patients who do not meet criteria for revascularization, such as this patient whose ankle-brachial index (ABI) is >0.5. Cilostazol is contraindicated in patients with heart failure due to increased mortality in these patients.

(Choice B) Pentoxifylline is indicated as a second-line treatment for PAD symptom relief, but controlled trials regarding efficacy are inconsistent and show limited benefit in improving walking capacity.

(Choice C) Current guidelines recommend revascularization therapy (either surgical or percutaneous) for patients who fail all exercise and medical therapy, for those with significant disabling claudication preventing daily activities, and those with limb-threatening ischemia (ABI usually ~0.5). This patient should receive further medical therapy before considering revascularization as she does not meet the above criteria.

(Choice D) Verapamil is an arterial vasodilator that modestly increases walking distance but has no effect on ABI, peripheral leg temperature or blood pressure, or PAD progression.

Educational objective:
Risk factor modification and graded exercise are effective in improving exercise capacity in patients with claudication and peripheral arterial disease (PAD). If lifestyle-limiting claudication persists, medical therapy with antiplatelet agents (aspirin or clopidogrel) is recommended to improve pain-free walking distance and prevent PAD progression. Patients who fail antiplatelet therapy and do not meet criteria for revascularization can be prescribed cilostazol to improve pain-free walking distances.

A 64-year-old man comes to the office for a routine follow-up. He has no current concerns. Last year, he underwent a transthoracic echocardiogram for a cardiac murmur and was diagnosed with mild calcific aortic stenosis. The mean gradient across the valve was 18 mm Hg (normal <5 mm Hg), and the estimated valve area was 1.6 cm (normal 3-4 cm). The patient does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. He jogs and bikes 3 times a week. Blood pressure is 136/78 mm Hg, and pulse is 77/min and regular. BMI is 29 kg/m². A 3/6 systolic ejection-type murmur is heard at the upper sternal border radiating to the carotids. S4 is heard at the apex at end-expiration. Lungs are clear to auscultation. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. ECG shows normal sinus rhythm with voltage criteria for left ventricular hypertrophy and nonspecific ST segment changes. Laboratory results are as follows:

Complete blood count
Hemoglobin 14.0 g/dL
Hematocrit 42%

Fasting lipid panel
Low-density lipoprotein 90 mg/dL

What is the best next step in management of this patient?
choice_c: No intervention and clinical follow-up in a year
explanation:
This patient with aortic stenosis (AS) has asymptomatic and mild (ie, transvalvular velocity 2-2.9 m/s, mean transvalvular gradient <20 mm Hg) valvular disease, Progression of AS is quite variable; however, the aortic valve area declines at an average rate of 0.1 cm/year in most patients. Most patients with mild to moderate AS remain asymptomatic for several years and should have routine clinical evaluation (eg, annually) to assess for new symptoms or signs of worsening AS. Patients with asymptomatic, mild AS should undergo serial echocardiogram every 3-5 years. Those with moderate AS should undergo echocardiogram every 1-2 years, and those with severe AS should have an echocardiogram every 6-12 months. Echocardiogram should be performed earlier than the standard interval if patients develop any new signs or symptoms of worsening AS (eg, chest pain, dyspnea, lower extremity edema, lightheadedness, syncope).

(Choice A) Pharmacologic therapy has no role in the management of patients with asymptomatic, mild AS. Beta blockers can be used in patients with mild to moderate AS and concurrent hypertension, coronary artery disease, or heart failure.

(Choice B) Antibiotic prophylaxis for endocarditis is indicated only for patients with the highest-risk cardiac conditions. It is not indicated in most patients with valvular heart disease, including those with bicuspid aortic valve and AS.

(Choice D) Unless symptoms consistent with worsening AS develop, echocardiogram is not indicated for another 2-4 years in this patient with mild AS.

(Choice E) There is no role for routine exercise stress testing in patients with asymptomatic, mild AS. It is occasionally performed in patients with asymptomatic, severe AS to confirm absence of symptoms.

Educational objective:
Serial echocardiogram is recommended every 3-5 years in patients with mild aortic stenosis (AS), every 1- 2 years in those with moderate AS, and every 6-12 months in those with asymptomatic, severe AS. Pharmacologic therapy has no role in the management of patients with mild AS in the absence of concurrent hypertension, coronary artery disease, or heart failure.

A 40-year-old man comes to the physician for an insurance physical. He has no current complaints. His medical problems include borderline hypertension and seasonal allergies. He takes fexofenadine. He does not smoke and drinks 1-2 alcoholic beverages per weekend. His family history is remarkable for an uncle who died suddenly in his 30s while playing basketball. His older brother had two unexplained syncopes.

His blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg, pulse is 88/min, and respirations are 12/min. The patient's pulse oximetry showed 98% on room air. His BMI is 23 kg/m². There is a 3/6 systolic murmur heard at the mid and upper sternum bilaterally. Carotid upstrokes are delayed. The intensity of the murmur decreases when the patient assumes a standing position from a sitting position. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
This patient's physical examination is consistent with aortic stenosis. Systolic ejection murmurs at the right upper sternal border imply turbulence in the left ventricular (LV) outflow tract due to aortic stenosis (AS), hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM), or supravalvular AS. Maneuvers that decrease LV cavity size (i.e., Valsalva, standing) cause the hypertrophied septum in HCM to obstruct further and make the murmur louder. Fixed obstructions, as seen in AS, get slightly quieter as the decreased venous return results in less flow across the fixed obstruction. Delayed pulses ("parvus et tardus") are characteristic of aortic stenosis, while patients with HCM have a "bifid" pulse (two systolic impulses collapsed in between due to ejection obstruction ejection during systole). Aortic stenosis is due to either "senile" (bicuspid valve) or fibrocalcific aortic stenosis, which results from calcification of a normal aortic valve (presents around age 70). Bicuspid aortic valves are a congenital anomaly which undergo accelerated fibrocalcification and cause symptoms around age 40. Rarer causes of aortic stenosis include endocarditis, connective tissue diseases, and prior radiation.

(Choice A) Ebstein's anomaly is due to abnormalities of the tricuspid leaflet structure and location. The murmur is usually due to tricuspid regurgitation (holosystolic at the left lower sternal border) that does not change with standing.

(Choice B) Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is a genetic disorder with significant hypertrophy of the LV septum or the entire left heart with outflow obstruction (about 30% of patients). Maneuvers that decrease LV volume (i.e., Valsalva, standing) will increase the gradient and the murmur; while maneuvers that increase LV volume or increase afterload will decrease the murmur (i.e., squatting, handgrip, leg lift).

(Choice C) The murmur produced by mitral valve prolapse is preceded by a click and heard best at the apex. Maneuvers that decrease LV filling (i.e., Valsalva, standing) make the murmur louder. Maneuvers that increase LV filling (i.e., squatting, leg raise) will improve the closure of the mitral leaflets, delay the click, and soften the murmur.

(Choice E) Ventricular septal defects produce a holosystolic, harsh murmur with a thrill along the left stemal border. The murmur does not typically change with standing.

Educational objective:
Maneuvers that decrease left ventricular cavity size (i.e., Valsalva, standing) cause the hypertrophied septum in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy to obstruct further and make the murmur louder. Fixed obstructions, such as aortic stenosis, get slightly quieter as the decreased venous return results in less flow across the fixed obstruction.

stem: A 72-year-old man with a history of heart failure and reduced ejection fraction comes to the office for follow- up. The patient reports no change in his chronic dyspnea on exertion but says he has had a persistent, nonproductive cough for the past 4 weeks. The cough occurs during the day and night, and he has not been able to get restful sleep. The patient has had no fever, chills, night sweats, or loss of appetite. In the past year, he has had several hospitalizations due to decompensated heart failure, and 6 months ago he was treated with coronary stenting for an episode of non-ST elevation myocardial infarction. A recent echocardiogram revealed a left ventricular ejection fraction of 30%. The patient's other medical problems include hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and osteoarthritis. He takes aspirin, ticagrelor, atorvastatin, furosemide, carvedilol, sacubitril-valsartan, and spironolactone. He smoked a half pack of cigarettes daily for 10 years, but quit at age 40. The patient does not use alcohol or illicit drugs. Temperature is 36.6 C (98 F), blood pressure is 106/60 mm Hg, pulse is 72/min and regular, and respirations are 16/min. Pulse oximetry shows 96% on ambient air. Weight is 75 kg (165.3 lb), unchanged from previous visits. Physical examination reveals normal nasal and oropharyngeal mucous membranes, poor dentition, normal jugular venous pressure, clear lungs, and a grade 2/6 systolic murmur at the left sternal border. The abdomen is soft and nontender with no hepatosplenomegaly. Trace bilateral lower extremity pitting edema is present. Chest x-ray reveals no parenchymal opacities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
choice_c: Obtain CT scan of the chest
choice_e: Prescribe a trial of proton pump inhibitor
explanation:
Neprilysin is an enzyme that degrades endogenous vasoactive peptides, including atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP), brain natriuretic peptide (BNP), bradykinin, and angiotensin II. Sacubitril inhibits neprilysin, resulting in elevated circulating levels of these vasoactive peptides. The elevated ANP and BNP levels promote diuresis and cause venous and arteriolar dilation, providing beneficial hemodynamic effects in patients with heart failure. However, these effects come at the expense of elevated angiotensin II levels, leading to vasoconstriction and fluid retention, and elevated bradykinin levels, sometimes leading to cough. To counteract the elevated angiotensin II levels, sacubitril is paired with an angiotensin II receptor blocker for clinical use. Compared to an ACE inhibitor (enalapril), sacubitril-valsartan reduces heart failure hospitalization and improves cardiovascular and all-cause mortality in patients with symptomatic heart failure with reduced ejection fraction. A nonproductive cough, similar to that seen in patients taking ACE inhibitors, occurs in approximately 10% of patients taking sacubitril-valsartan, and is sometimes use-limiting. Other adverse effects include hypotension, hyperkalemia, dizziness, renal failure, and (rarely) angioedema.

(Choice B) This patient has stable weight, normal pulmonary examination and chest x-ray, and only trace pedal edema. It is unlikely that fluid overload is responsible for his cough, and increasing the dose of furosemide is not indicated.

(Choices C and D) CT scan of the chest and pulmonary function testing allow evaluation for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and interstitial lung disease (ILD), both of which can cause chronic cough. However, the absence of sputum production and pulmonary crackles makes COPD and ILD, respectively, less likely.

(Choice E) Cough due to gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) often responds to a trial of a proton pump inhibitor. However, in the absence of other signs or symptoms suggestive of GERD (eg, heartburn, regurgitation), discontinuing sacubitril, a known cause of cough, is initially preferred.

Educational objective:
Sacubitril inhibits neprilysin, resulting in elevated levels of atrial natriuretic peptide, brain natriuretic peptide, bradykinin, and angiotensin II. Sacubitril-valsartan improves cardiovascular mortality but causes a nonproductive cough, similar to that seen with ACE inhibitors, in approximately 10% of patients.

A 62-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of chest and upper abdominal discomfort for the past 6 months. He has noted the discomfort during his daily walks and sometimes at rest, especially after heavy meals. His other medical problems include hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and gastroesophageal reflux disease. His medications include metformin, aspirin, hydrochlorothiazide, and lisinopril.

The patient's blood pressure is 142/82 mm Hg and pulse is 74/min. BMI is 33 kg/m². His physical examination is remarkable for chronic venous stasis and 1+ swelling of both lower extremities. The patient is referred for an exercise radionuclide stress test. After 5 minutes on the Bruce protocol, he is able to reach 85% of maximum age-predicted heart rate. His blood pressure at baseline is 148/88 mm Hg and is 142/86 mm Hg at peak exercise. He complains of discomfort in both arms and his chest during the end of exercise, which resolves 5 minutes later during the recovery period. ECG monitoring shows 2-mm horizontal ST-segment depression in leads II, aVF, and V4-V6 at peak stress with normalization at recovery. However, myocardial perfusion images show no evidence of ischemia, and ejection fraction is calculated at 65%. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
choice_a: Add clopidogrel and nitroglycerin as needed
choice_b: Evaluate for noncardiac cause of chest pain
choice_d: Reassure and follow up in 3-6 months
explanation:
Exercise ECG stress testing provides both diagnostic and prognostic information in patients with suspected coronary artery disease. Positive stress test findings, noted in the table, are often associated with poor outcomes if not treated. This patient was found to have ST depression in multiple leads during peak stress but no evidence of ischemia on radionuclide myocardial perfusion imaging. This is suggestive of the presence of balanced ischemia. Balanced ischemia is present when coronary flow is equally or nearly equally impaired. As a result, the pattern of perfusion on the radionuclide myocardial image appears mostly homogenous, creating a false negative. Therefore, the next step in management is to proceed with coronary angiography to look for significant multivessel obstructive coronary artery disease.

Educational objective:
The presence of high-risk features on exercise stress testing and normal radionuclide myocardial perfusion imaging should raise suspicion for the presence of balanced ischemia. Such patients should be further evaluated with coronary angiography for the presence of multivessel coronary artery disease.

A 32-year-old man comes to the clinic after experiencing heart palpitations. He is concerned as his uncle died suddenly at age 35.

During physical examination, the physician asks the patient to sit up, lean forward, and hold his breath in full expiration while placing the diaphragm of the stethoscope at the left sternal border and applying firm pressure. Which of the following findings is best auscultated with this maneuver?
choice_b: Mid-systolic click of mitral valve prolapse
explanation:
The maneuver in the question is best suited for auscultating an aortic regurgitation murmur. Aortic regurgitation leads to an early decrescendo diastolic murmur that begins immediately after A2 (aortic component of second heart sound) and ends prior to the start of S1. The murmur is usually high pitched, blowing in quality, and best heard along the left sternal border at the 3rd and 4th intercostal space. Breath sounds can completely obscure the murmur in some patients. As a result, it is often best to instruct patients to sit up and lean forward while holding their breath in full expiration. Auscultation should be performed using the diaphragm of the stethoscope while applying firm pressure.

(Choice B) Mitral valve prolapse (MVP) is associated with a single/multiple mid-systolic click and mid-to- late systolic murmur of mitral regurgitation. Standing or Valsalva causes an earlier systolic click and longer murmur (due to decreased left ventricular volume/size); squatting or leg elevation causes a delayed systolic click and shorter murmur (due to increased left ventricular volume/size). The maneuver performed on this patient does not affect mitral valve prolapse.

(Choice C) Mitral stenosis is associated with an opening snap (OS) of the mitral valve and a low-pitched rumbling murmur heard throughout diastole. This is best heard when the patient is in the left lateral decubitus position with the stethoscope bell at the cardiac apex.

(Choice D) Pulmonic stenosis causes an ejection systolic click with an associated systolic ejection murmur that is best heard over the left second intercostal space with radiation to the left side of the neck. The closure of the pulmonary valve is delayed due to the stenosis, causing splitting of S2. Pulmonic stenosis intensity increases with inspiration and decreases with abrupt standing.

(Choice E) A third heart sound (S3) is best heard when the patient is in the left lateral decubitus position with the stethoscope bell at the cardiac apex.

Educational objective:
Aortic regurgitation murmurs are best heard when the patient is sitting up, leaning forward, and holding their breath in full expiration while the diaphragm of the stethoscope is placed along the left sternal border at the 3rd or 4th intercostal space.

stem:
A 43-year-old woman is being evaluated for a heart murmur. She is physically active and takes a yoga class three times a week without difficulty. She exercises on a treadmill twice per week. She denies any chest pain or pressure, palpitations, and shortness of breath. She had arthroscopic knee surgery two years ago after sustaining a knee injury while running. Otherwise, her past medical history is unremarkable.

Her blood pressure is 122/78 mm Hg and pulse is 67/min. Her BMI is 25 kg/m² There is a blowing 3/6 holosystolic murmur heard best at the apex. Lungs are clear on auscultation. Her physical examination is otherwise unremarkable. EKG shows normal sinus rhythm with non-specific ST segment and T wave changes. Echocardiogram shows normal left ventricular size and function, an ejection fraction of 65%, and posterior mitral leaflet prolapse with severe eccentric mitral regurgitation. Left atrial size is moderately increased. Pulmonary artery systolic pressure is estimated at 25 mm Hg. Which of the following is the best recommendation for this patient?
choice_a: Antibiotic prophylaxis prior to dental work
explanation:
This patient has mitral valve prolapse with significant mitral regurgitation (MR), as evidenced by the echocardiogram (ECHO). Patients with chronic severe mitral regurgitation require intervention (mitral valve repair preferred over replacement) if they develop symptoms (i.e., shortness of breath), echocardiographic evidence of cardiac dysfunction (e.g., an ejection fraction < 60% or an end systolic dimension > 40 mm), pulmonary hypertension (i.e., PAP > 50 mm Hg), or new onset atrial fibrillation (Choice D). Asymptomatic patients require serial monitoring, with the frequency depending on the severity of MR as seen on ECHO. This patient with severe mitral regurgitation and no cardiac dysfunction should be evaluated with serial clinical and echocardiographic follow-up every 6-12 months.

(Choice A) Current guidelines recommend antibiotic prophylaxis in patients with valvular heart disease repaired with prosthetic valve or prosthetic material (i.e., a mitral or tricuspid ring), history of prior endocarditis, congenital heart disease (e.g., unrepaired cyanotic, within 6 months of repaired congenital heart disease, or repaired congenital heart disease with residual defects), or cardiac transplant with an abnormal valve and regurgitation.

(Choice B) Anticoagulation is not indicated in the absence of documented atrial fibrillation (common in mitral valve disease).

(Choice C) This patient is very physically active without any cardiovascular symptoms, and therefore has no indication for coronary angiography.

Educational objective:
Patients with chronic mitral regurgitation (MR) require mitral valve repair if they become symptomatic, show echocardiographic (ECHO) evidence of cardiac dysfunction, develop pulmonary hypertension, or new- onset atrial fibrillation. Asymptomatic patients need serial monitoring with clinical exam and ECHO depending on the severity of the MR.

A 54-year-old man comes to the physician with fatigue and decreased exercise tolerance over the last 6 months. He denies cough, chest pain, syncope, or weight loss. He had aortic valve replacement with a mechanical valve due to bicuspid aortic valve stenosis 7 years ago. Coronary angiography prior to surgery showed no evidence of coronary artery disease. His medications include warfarin and antacids for occasional heartburn.

His blood pressure is 122/70 mm Hg and pulse is 89/min and regular. Jugular venous pressure is estimated at 9 cm H2O. A faint early diastolic murmur is heard at the left sternal border. Lungs are clear on auscultation. The liver span is 9 cm, and the tip of the spleen is not palpable. There is no edema of the lower extremities.

Laboratory results are as follows:

Hemoglobin: 9.2 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume: 89 fL
Platelets: 140,000/ μL
International normalized ratio: 2.7
Lactate dehydrogenase, serum: 1,600 U/L
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate: 35 mm/h

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
This patient's early diastolic murmur is likely due to aortic regurgitation, which could be from structural failure of a mechanical valve or infective endocarditis. He also has anemia with elevated LDH, suggesting a hemolytic process. Hemolytic anemia is due to destruction of erythrocytes by malfunctioning valve and is more common with prosthetic mechanical valves than bioprosthetic valves. Patients often present with fatigue, jaundice, dark urine, and a new or changing heart murmur. Anemia, indirect hyperbilirubinemia, and elevated serum lactate dehydrogenase are present. Peripheral smear shows schistocytes. Anemia is often mild and is treated with oral iron or periodic blood transfusions. In certain cases of paravalvular leak, the valve may need to be replaced.

(Choice A) Colonic angiodysplasia is a common cause of lower GI bleed and is sometimes found in patients with aortic stenosis. In most patients, bleeding improves after valve replacement. This patient's normal MCV and markedly elevated LDH make iron deficiency anemia from GI bleeding unlikely.

(Choice C) This patient has no symptoms of large-vessel vasculitis (eg, giant cell or Takayasu) such as fever, weight loss, headache, or jaw/arm claudication.

(Choice D) Patients with lymphoma usually present with lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, B symptoms (fever, weight loss, night sweats), and possibly a rapidly growing mass. Although lymphoma can cause elevated LDH, this patient does not have these other symptoms.

(Choice E) While infective endocarditis can result in valve failure, this patient has no fever, leukocytosis, or signs of embolic phenomena.

Educational objective:
Hemolytic anemia is a complication of prosthetic heart valves. Treatment involves oral iron or blood transfusion. Patients with paravalvular leak or valve failure may need valve replacement.

stem: A 23-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of a murmur. He has no complaints and describes his exercise tolerance as 'excellent.' He has no other medical conditions and takes no medications. He does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. His paternal uncle died from an unknown cause at a young age. Physical examination reveals a IV/VI holosystolic murmur which is best heard at the fourth intercostal space along the left sternal border. It is accompanied by a palpable thrill. Carotid pulses are 2+ bilaterally without delay. Otherwise, his physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
This asymptomatic patient's murmur is most likely due to the presence of a ventricular septal defect (VSD). A VSD causes a loud holosystolic murmur with maximal intensity over the third or fourth left intercostal space along the left sternal border, accompanied by a systolic thrill. This patient likely has a small VSD and is relatively asymptomatic. Observation would be the ideal management in this patient since the VSD closes spontaneously in up to 10% of adults. However, patients who progress will develop symptoms of volume overload, left ventricular dilatation, and have an increased chance of endocarditis. Surgery is indicated for patients who develop any of these complications and/or significant Eisenmenger syndrome.

(Choice A) The low velocity flow across an atrial septal defect does not result in a murmur. A large defect causes a mid-systolic pulmonic ejection murmur due to increased flow across the pulmonic valve. This is best heard in the left second intercostal space and is usually not associated with a palpable thrill.

(Choice B) The presence of a bicuspid aortic valve typically causes a prominent ejection click followed by a mid-systolic murmur heard best over the right second intercostal space. In severe aortic stenosis, carotid pulses are delayed and diminished in amplitude (parvus et tardus).

(Choice C) Ebstein anomaly is characterized by apical displacement of the tricuspid valve leaflets, decreased volume of the right ventricle, and atrialization of the right ventricle. It is associated with tricuspid regurgitation, which results in a holosystolic murmur best heard over left second or third intercostal space or at the subxiphoid area. A thrill is not usually palpable.

(Choice D) Supravalvular aortic stenosis causes a loud ejection systolic murmur which is best heard over right first intercostal space. A thrill is palpable in the suprasternal notch or the right first intercostal space.

Educational objective:
Ventricular septal defects cause a loud holosystolic murmur which is best heard over the third or fourth intercostal space along the left sternal border. It can be distinguished from other systolic murmurs by its characteristic location and presence of a palpable thrill.

stem: A 29-year-old woman comes to the physician accompanied by her husband for an initial consultation. She has no current symptoms. She is physically active and walks for 45 minutes on a treadmill 3-4 days a week. She has a past history of "heart failure," which was diagnosed 1 week after the birth of her first child 2 years ago. She was found to have a reduced LV ejection fraction of 25%, but further evaluation did not reveal any specific cause of her cardiomyopathy. She has been taking daily furosemide, potassium supplements, carvedilol, and quinapril since that time. Her last echocardiogram 2 months ago showed an improved LV ejection fraction of 40%, mild left atrial enlargement, and mild mitral regurgitation. The couple is contemplating another pregnancy and was referred by the obstetrician for a second opinion. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation?
explanation:
This patient's history is consistent with peripartum cardiomyopathy (PPCM), an uncommon cause of heart failure. The etiology is unknown but may be multifactorial (e.g., immune-mediated, myocarditis, etc.). Risk factors for PPCM include age > 30, multiparity, African descent, pregnancy with multiple fetuses, maternal cocaine use, and beta-agonist (e.g., terbutaline) use > 4 weeks. Patients typically present with heart failure symptoms (usually dyspnea) and are diagnosed based on clinical criteria and an echocardiogram. Peripartum cardiomyopathy treatment is similar to usual heart failure therapy, but ACE inhibitors and ARBS are teratogenic and should not be taken during pregnancy (Choice B). Diuretics relieve pulmonary congestion, but loop diuretics are preferred over thiazide diuretics due to increased risk of fetal bleeding diathesis. Beta-1 selective blockers are generally preferred due to decreased risk of uterine relaxation and peripheral vasodilation. Digoxin is only considered in symptomatic patients who fail first-line therapies. One major predictor of persistent LV dysfunction is LV ejection fraction (EF) < 30% at the time of diagnosis. Patients who recover LV function to normal have a lower risk of complications during subsequent pregnancies, but their risk is still elevated when compared to the general population. Patients with persistent LV dysfunction have a substantially higher risk of complications such as significant decline in LVEF, recurrent heart failure, and death and should avoid subsequent pregnancies. This patient is stable but still has a depressed LVEF. She should avoid pregnancy and continue her present medications (Choices C, D, and E).

Educational objective:
Patients with a history of peripartum cardiomyopathy and persistent LV dysfunction have a high risk of further decline in LV function, recurrent heart failure, and death with subsequent pregnancies. Such patients should be advised to avoid future pregnancy.

A 25-year-old woman comes to the physician with complaints of fatigue and worsening shortness of breath. She first noticed her symptoms 8 months ago. She awoke 2 days ago with palpitations and severe coughing and noticed some bright-colored blood in her sputum. She emigrated from the Philippines 2 years ago and works as a nurse at a local hospital. She has no history of smoking, illicit drug use, or unprotected sexual intercourse. She has no past medical history of childhood illnesses.

Her blood pressure is 106/62 mm Hg, and pulse is 82/min and regular. Neck veins are pulsatile with a prominent c-v wave. Lungs fields are clear with minimal rales heard at both lung bases. Heart sounds are regular with a loud first heart sound. A low-pitched mid-diastolic rumble and a snapping sound after the second heart sound are present at the cardiac apex. There is also a loud holosystolic murmur heard over the precordium that increases with inspiration. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
The diagnosis of mitral stenosis is suspected based on clinical presentation and typical demographics and is confirmed with classic findings on physical examination. This patient's episode of paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea and hemoptysis was most likely precipitated by paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. Classic physical examination findings in patients with mitral stenosis include a loud first heart sound, opening snap after S2 (best heard at the apex), and a low-pitched mid-diastolic rumble best heard at the cardiac apex using the bell of the stethoscope with the patient lying on the left side in held expiration. Patients with pulmonary hypertension and tricuspid regurgitation have pulsatile neck veins and a prominent c-v wave on jugular venous pulsation. Tricuspid regurgitation causes a holosystolic murmur best heard along the left sternal border that increases in intensity with inspiration.

(Choice A) An early diastolic murmur, best heard at the left sternal border, is characteristic for aortic regurgitation. Opening snap is not present.

(Choice B) Patients with constrictive pericarditis have elevated JVP with prominent "y" descent, Kussmaul's sign (lack of decline in JVP with inspiration), and an audible pericardial knock. There are no associated murmurs.

(Choice C) Ebstein's anomaly is a congenital malformation characterized by abnormalities of the tricuspid valve and right ventricle. Auscultation reveals a tricuspid regurgitation murmur similar to that heard in this patient; however, mid-diastolic rumble at the cardiac apex is not common in adults. Also, first and second heart sounds are widely split due to right bundle branch block. Opening snap is not present.

(Choice E) Ventricular septal defect causes a loud holosystolic murmur, along with a palpable thrill, and is best appreciated over the third or fourth left intercostal space along the left sternal border.

Educational objective:
Physical examination findings in patients with mitral stenosis include a loud first heart sound, opening snap after S2 (best heard at the apex), and a low-pitched diastolic rumble best heard at the cardiac apex. Patients with tricuspid regurgitation from long-standing pulmonary hypertension also have a holosystolic murmur that increases in intensity with inspiration.

stem:
A 79-year-old woman is referred for perioperative evaluation prior to cataract surgery. Medical history is significant for hypertension, heart failure, mild intermittent asthma, gout, and nonvalvular atrial fibrillation for which she takes warfarin. Medications also include lisinopril, furosemide, carvedilol, and amlodipine. The patient has no history of stroke. Two weeks ago, the INR was 2.5.

Blood pressure is 130/82 mm Hg and pulse is 84/min and irregular. Jugular venous pressure is normal and the lungs are clear to auscultation. The patient has a grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at the right upper sternal border without radiation. Pedal edema is not present.

What is the best way to manage this patient's anticoagulation?
choice_a: Continue warfarin with no change in dosing or target INR
choice_b: Discontinue warfarin 5 days prior to procedure and perform perioperative bridging with heparin
choice_c: Hold warfarin until the INR normalizes, then restart warfarin postprocedure with no bridging
choice_e: Reduce warfarin dose and adjust target INR to 1.5 preoperatively
explanation:
Management of perioperative anticoagulation with warfarin requires consideration of the surgical risk of bleeding weighed against the perioperative thrombotic risk if anticoagulation is stopped: 

• Low-bleeding-risk surgeries or procedures (eg, cataract surgery, central venous catheter removal) do not typically require adjustment or interruption in the warfarin regimen, regardless of thrombotic risk. 
• High-bleeding-risk surgeries (eg, joint replacement) require a temporary interruption in anticoagulation. For patients at very high thrombotic risk (eg, CHA2DS2 Vasc score 26), the interruption in anticoagulation should be accompanied by perioperative bridging (eg, low-molecular-weight heparin, unfractionated heparin) (Choice B). 

This patient with atrial fibrillation and a CHA2DS2-Vasc score of 5 is at high perioperative thrombotic risk but is undergoing a low-bleeding-risk surgery (cataract); therefore, continuation of warfarin is appropriate. Temporary interruption of warfarin without perioperative bridging would have been appropriate if he had been undergoing a high-bleeding-risk surgery (Choice C). 

(Choices D and E) Neither permanent discontinuation of warfarin nor temporary reduction in the target INR is a viable strategy for managing perioperative bleeding and thrombotic risk in this patient requiring warfarin for atrial fibrillation.

Educational objective:
Management of perioperative anticoagulation with warfarin involves balancing the bleeding risk of surgery with the thrombotic risk of stopping anticoagulation. Low-bleeding-risk surgeries or procedures (eg, cataract surgery) typically require no adjustment or interruption in the warfarin regimen. High-bleeding-risk surgeries (eg, joint replacement) require a temporary interruption in anticoagulation; the interruption should be accompanied by bridging (eg, low-molecular-weight heparin, unfractionated heparin) in patients at very high thrombotic risk.

A 62-year-old man comes to the office to follow up hypertension. He has a long history of hypertension treated with amlodipine and obstructive sleep apnea requiring continuous positive airway pressure at night. The patient does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs and has no medication allergies. Blood pressure is 134/90 mm Hg and pulse is 78/min. BMI is 33 kg/m². Physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory results are as follows:

Serum chemistry
Creatinine: 0.8 mg/dL
Glucose: 102 mg/dL

Fasting lipid panel
HDL: 40 mg/dl
LDL: 190 mg/dL
TSH: 3.8 μU/mL

Liver function tests are normal. The patient is counseled on indications for lipid-lowering therapy with statin drugs. He is at greatest risk for which of the following adverse effects if he starts high-intensity atorvastatin therapy?
explanation:
Hydroxymethylglutaryl-coenzyme A reductase inhibitors (statins) lower LDL and VLDL cholesterol and triglycerides and have been shown to prevent cardiovascular events, with most studies indicating a relative risk reduction of approximately 20%-30%. They are indicated for patients with established atherosclerotic disease and those age 40-75 with diabetes mellitus. Patients with LDL cholesterol ≥190 mg/dL (as in this patient) are at very high risk for coronary events and also should be treated with statins, as should those who have a calculated 10-year risk for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease 27.5%. Recent studies have shown that high-intensity statin therapy may increase the risk of new-onset diabetes or worsen glycemic control in established diabetes. The risk is dose dependent and is greater in older patients and women. However, this excess risk of developing diabetes is markedly outweighed by the reduction in risk for cardiovascular events; therefore, the benefits of statin therapy outweigh the adverse effects on blood glucose. New-onset or worsening diabetes does not warrant discontinuation of statin therapy.

(Choice A) Hepatic dysfunction due to statin use is uncommon (0.5%-3%) and usually resolves without sequelae if the medication is withheld. Acute liver failure and cirrhosis are extremely rare.

(Choice B) Statins are associated with an increased risk for hemorrhagic stroke; however, the excess risk is very small (-0.05%-0.1% over 5 years).

(Choice D) Patients with hypothyroidism may be more susceptible to statin-induced myopathy, and many experts advise checking a serum TSH level prior to initiation of therapy. However, statins do not cause hypothyroidism.

(Choice E) Statins have a 2%-10% risk of inducing myalgia (the most common side effect) but only a 0.1% risk for rhabdomyolysis. Muscle symptoms are most likely in patients with pre-existing liver or renal disease or hypothyroidism. Patients with statin myopathy should discontinue the medication until symptoms improve and then be considered for a statin less likely to cause muscle toxicity (eg, pravastatin, rosuvastatin).

Educational objective:
Statins are associated with an increased risk of diabetes and worsening glycemic control in patients with established diabetes mellitus. However, this excess risk is significantly less than the reduction in risk for cardiovascular events. The benefits of statin therapy outweigh the adverse effects on blood glucose, and new-onset or worsening diabetes does not warrant discontinuation of statin therapy.

stem: A 64-year-old man comes to the physician with a 2-week history of lightheadedness. He describes episodes of feeling woozy and a sense of heaviness in his head with squatting as he worked in his garden. He also describes occasional headaches that have recently become worse. He has no palpitations and has not lost consciousness. He has known nonischemic cardiomyopathy with a biventricular automatic implantable cardioverter defibrillator placed 2 years ago and a lead revision 1 month ago. Three weeks ago, an echocardiogram showed a left ventricular ejection fraction of 30%. His supine blood pressure is 122/75 mm Hg, standing blood pressure is 125/78 mm Hg, and pulse is 60/min. Examination shows a plethoric face. The neck and upper chest veins are distended. No enlarged lymph nodes are palpated. A 2/6 holosystolic murmur radiating to the axilla is heard at the apex. Lungs are clear to auscultation. The liver span is 10 cm. There is trace bilateral edema of the lower extremities. Symmetrical pulses are palpated on the upper and lower extremities bilaterally. Electrocardiogram shows atrioventricular sequential pacing. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
This patient's clinical presentation (presyncope during squatting and worsening headaches) after recent automatic implantable cardioverter defibrillator (AICD) lead revision suggests superior vena cava (SVC) syndrome. SVC syndrome is most commonly due to tumor compression. However, transvenous AICD implantation can induce thrombosis and occlusion around the leads, resulting in SVC syndrome. Although the body tries to offset the high venous pressure by creating venous collaterals, central venous pressure usually remains high and causes symptoms. Risk factors for SVC include the number of ICD leads, endothelial damage during insertion, thrombophilic state, and infections. Symptoms may develop any time after AICD implantation but usually occur 1-15 months after the procedure. Typical manifestations include dyspnea, head fullness, facial/arm swelling, or chest wall edema that may worsen with bending or lying down. Patients may also develop episodic syncope or presyncope. Bilateral upper-extremity venography is the gold standard for diagnosing SVC syndrome. However, contrast-enhanced chest computed tomography is usually done first to show the extent of the venous blockage, visualize collaterals, and possibly identify the causative factor. Therapy usually involves long- term anticoagulation. Patients with more extensive clot or severe symptoms may require thrombolysis, stent implantation, bypass surgery, or extraction of the leads and re-implantation.

(Choice A) Constrictive pericarditis usually presents with worsening peripheral edema or anasarca and extreme fatigability, especially in response to exertion. Physical examination shows an elevated jugular venous pressure, pulsus paradoxus, Kussmaul's sign, and pericardial knock.

(Choice B) Pancoast tumor usually invades the brachial plexus, parietal pleura, surrounding fascia, ribs. and vertebral bodies. Patients typically present with shoulder pain, Horner's syndrome, and hand muscle weakness/atrophy.

(Choice C) Subclavian steal syndrome is usually due to atherosclerotic narrowing of the proximal subclavian artery, which results in flow reversal in the ipsilateral vertebral artery. This occurs most often on the left side, and many patients are asymptomatic. A significant percentage has symptoms of arterial insufficiency in the affected upper extremity (eg, exercise-induced fatigue, pain, numbness, coolness, fatigue). Some patients have symptoms relative to vertebral-basilar artery insufficiency (eg, dizziness, vertigo, disequilibrium, drop attacks).

(Choice E) Ventricular arrhythmias would not explain this patient's dilated neck and upper chest veins.

Educational objective:
Superior vena cava (SVC) syndrome is most commonly due to tumor compression. However, implantation of a transvenous automatic implantable cardioverter defibrillator can induce thrombosis and occlusion around the leads, resulting in SVC syndrome. Bilateral upper-extremity venography is the gold standard for diagnosing SVC syndrome. However, contrast-enhanced chest computed tomography is usually the initial test of choice.

stem: A 62-year-old man complains of right-sided leg and thigh pain while walking. The pain improves with rest and is described as a heaviness or cramping sensation. His sexual performance has decreased over the past year. The patient's other medical problems include chronic kidney disease, type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and gastroesophageal reflux disease. He has a 38-pack-year smoking history. The patient's blood pressure is 144/72 mm Hg, pulse is 67/min, and body mass index is 29 kg/m² A bruit is heard over the right carotid artery. Peripheral pulses are palpable bilaterally. There is a small ulcer at the tip of the right big toe. No extremity edema is present. The ankle-brachial index is 1.45 on the right and 1.40 on the left (normal 1.0-1.3). The serum creatinine is 2.2 mg/dL and HbA1c is 7.5%. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's leg pain?
explanation:
This patient has several risk factors, along with clinical symptoms and signs (intermittent claudication, erectile dysfunction, lower-extremity ulceration) suggestive of occlusive peripheral arterial disease (PAD). Measurement of ankle-brachial index (ABI) is recommended in such patients to confirm the diagnosis of PAD. An ABI of 1.0-1.3 is considered normal; in symptomatic patients, an ABI of ≤0.90 is considered diagnostic of occlusive PAD with 90% sensitivity and 95% specificity. Some patients with PAD and arterial calcification have non-compressible vessels, which can lead to falsely elevated ABI (>1.3). This is usually seen in the setting of diabetes mellitus and/or chronic renal failure. In such patients, further vascular studies, with measurement of toe-brachial index, pulse volume recordings, or arterial duplex ultrasound should be obtained to confirm the diagnosis of PAD. The presence of high ABI >1.3 (similar to low ABI) is associated with an increased risk of all-cause and cardiovascular mortality.

(Choice A) Diabetic neuropathy usually presents with bilateral sensory polyneuropathy involving the distal lower extremities, with decreased sensation to light touch, pain, and temperature, and loss of vibration sense and proprioception. Patients with florid neuropathy also complain of pain, paresthesias, or dysesthesias of their feet. The quality and exertional pattern of this patient's symptoms are not consistent with diabetic neuropathy.

(Choice C) Lumbar spinal stenosis typically presents with "neurogenic claudication," with bilateral or asymmetric lower-extremity pain, weakness, or sensory loss that is exacerbated with walking or prolonged standing in erect postures. It is relieved with sitting or assuming a stooped and flexed posture.

(Choice D) Statin-induced myopathy generally develops within weeks to months after starting statins and can present with muscle weakness, myalgias, and myositis (with elevated creatine kinase). The symptoms are usually more diffuse (and not localized as in this patient) and affect both upper and lower extremities.

(Choice E) "Venous claudication" is occasionally used to describe the lower-extremity discomfort in patients with chronic venous disease. These patients usually have associated findings of venous disease with leg swelling and varicosities, and the symptoms are worse with the limbs in a prolonged dependent position.

Educational objective:
A falsely elevated ankle-brachial index (ABI) >1.3 can be present due to calcified and non-compressible arteries in patients with advanced peripheral arterial disease in the setting of diabetes and/or chronic renal failure. High ABI (similar to low ABI) is associated with an increased risk of all-cause and cardiovascular mortality.

stem: A 69-year-old man comes to the office with a 4-week history of fatigue. He feels "drained" by the end of the day. He has no chest pain, shortness of breath, or body aches but does have decreased exercise tolerance. He reports good appetite and no recent weight changes. His medications include amlodipine for hypertension and rosuvastatin for hyperlipidemia. His temperature is 36.8 C (98.3 F) and blood pressure is 144/90 mm Hg. Body mass index is 22 kg/m². Initial laboratory studies show hemoglobin of 14.2 g/dL, serum potassium of 4.6 mEq/L and serum creatinine of 0.8 mg/dL Fasting glucose level is 98 mg/dL. Electrocardiogram is shown here. Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
explanation:
This patient's presentation is consistent with atrial fibrillation (AF). Electrocardiogram shows an irregularly irregular rhythm with varying R-R intervals and no clearly discernible P waves. Patients may be asymptomatic but typically present with chest pain, dyspnea, palpitations, weakness, decreased exercise tolerance, dizziness, or presyncope. AF is the most common supraventricular arrhythmia and can occur due to a variety of cardiac and/or systemic disorders. Patients with hyperthyroidism have an increased risk of developing AF, and the risk is also increased in those with subclinical hyperthyroidism (low serum thyroid-stimulating hormone [TSH] and normal serum T4 concentration in clinically euthyroid patients). As a result, all patients with new-onset AF should have serum TSH levels obtained as part of initial evaluation for early diagnosis and appropriate management of hyperthyroidism.

(Choice A) Ankle brachial index measurement is used to detect peripheral arterial disease in patients with intermittent claudication.

(Choice B) Patients using statin drugs (eg, rosuvastatin) can develop statin-induced myopathy with myalgia, muscle weakness, and/or elevation of serum creatine kinase levels. This patient has no such signs/symptoms.

(Choice D) Treadmill exercise stress test may be used for diagnosis in patients with an intermediate probability of coronary artery disease. Atrial fibrillation is usually not associated with stable coronary heart disease and is also a relative contraindication to exercise treadmill testing.

(Choice E) Urine albumin excretion is increased in patients with glomerular diseases (eg, focal or diffuse glomerulonephritis, nephrotic syndrome) and in systemic illnesses such as diabetes mellitus. The presence of albuminuria (micro or macro) has been found to be associated with a higher AF risk; however, routine measurement of urine albumin levels is not recommended.

Educational objective:
Patients with clinical or subclinical hyperthyroidism have a higher risk of developing atrial fibrillation (AF). Serum thyroid-stimulating hormone levels should be measured during the initial evaluation of all patients with new-onset AF.

stem: A 77-year-old woman comes to the physician because she "passed out." She says that over the last few months she has had several episodes where she feels very lightheaded and must sit down. On one occasion, she did actually lose consciousness and hit her head against a bathroom counter. There are no clear precipitants of these episodes. She denies chest pain or pressure. She thinks that she is more short of breath while playing tennis than she used to be in the past. Her other medical problems include hypertension and mild chronic kidney disease. Her medications include amlodipine, lisinopril, simvastatin, and aspirin. Her blood pressure is 115/70 mm Hg, pulse is 62/min, and BMI is 23 kg/m². The patient is in no acute distress. There is a normal S1 and a soft S2. There is a III/VI mid-peaking systolic ejection murmur at the right upper sternal border that radiates to both carotid arteries. Her lungs are clear to auscultation. Her abdomen is soft and non-distended. Peripheral pulses are 2+ and symmetric. An echocardiogram showed normal left ventricular function, mild left ventricular hypertrophy, and moderate calcific aortic stenosis with an estimated aortic valve area of 1.4 cm (normal 3-4 cm). The patient was given a 24-hour Holter monitor. The tracing below was recorded at 1:25 pm. Which of the following would be the best next step in managing this patient?
choice_b: Discontinuation of amlodipine with close follow-up
explanation:
This patient presents with syncope, most likely due to AV heart block as seen on the EKG. Neurocardiogenic (vasovagal or vasodepressor) syncope is the most common diagnosis in young and middle-aged populations. Left ventricular outflow obstruction and arrhythmias are more common in the elderly. After a thorough history and physical examination, many patients require further testing (e.g.. EKG, echocardiogram, stress test) to rule out structural heart disease. Patients with an unclear etiology should undergo ambulatory recording with a Holter monitor, mobile telemetry, or an implantable loop recorder. This patient's Holter shows high degree AV block with non-conducted p waves in the middle of the second strip continuing into the third. While this particular episode did not cause syncope, it strongly suggests that AV block is the etiology of her symptoms. Syncope due to advanced AV block is a class I indication for permanent pacing.

(Choice A) Aortic valve replacement is reserved for symptomatic severe aortic stenosis (mean gradient > 40 mm Hg or aortic valve area < 1 cm on echocardiogram), which usually presents with syncope. However, this patient's echocardiogram shows moderate aortic stenosis that does not warrant valve replacement. The calcification that causes the aortic stenosis is also probably the same process that causes the degeneration of the conduction system.

(Choice B) Patients with syncope may wait to see if symptoms improve after withholding AV nodal blockers such as beta blockers, non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (e.g.. verapamil or diltiazem,), and digoxin. However, this patient is taking a dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker (e.g.. amlodipine, felodipine, nifedipine) that does not significantly affect the AV node.

(Choice C) A stress test may help diagnose coronary artery disease, but this patient has no chest pain with these episodes. Her Holter also shows no ST segment changes, which makes the AV block less likely due to ischemia.

(Choice E) Upright tilt testing has limited sensitivity and specificity for vasovagal syncope and usually does not help guide the patient's treatment. Also, the hemodynamic response during the test does not always reproduce the actual syncopal mechanism. Tilt testing can be employed in patients with recurrent unexplained syncope when other cardiac causes have been excluded with prolonged EKG monitoring (e.g.. loop recorders).

Educational objective:
In the evaluation of syncope, it is critical to first rule out structural heart disease. If none is found, then ambulatory monitoring can be very helpful. Syncope due to high degree AV block is a class I indication for permanent pacemaker placement.

stem: A 35-year-old woman comes to the office for a routine physical examination. She is in good health and has no significant medical history. The patient does not use tobacco or alcohol. She takes no medications or supplements. Her paternal aunt had an unexpected death at age 32. Physical examination, including cardiac examination, is unremarkable. ECG shows normal sinus rhythm with a corrected QT interval of 505 msec. Serum electrolytes are normal. Echocardiogram shows normal heart structure and function. The patient is advised about lifestyle modification and medication safety. Which of the following is the best initial management for this patient?
explanation:
This patient's presentation - prolonged corrected QT interval (QTc) and family history of sudden death - is suggestive of congenital long QT syndrome (LQTS). A normal QTc interval is 370-440 msec. A QTC >450 msec in male patients and >470 msec in female patients is considered a prolonged QT interval. Patients with congenital LQTS may be asymptomatic or have palpitations, presyncope/syncope, seizures, or cardiac arrest. LQTS is associated with an increased risk of ventricular arrhythmias, such as torsades de pointes, which may terminate spontaneously or degenerate into ventricular fibrillation. Management includes avoidance of conditions (eg, strenuous exercise, electrolyte abnormalities such as hypokalemia or hypomagnesemia) and medications (eg, antipsychotics, fluoroquinolones) that may prolong the QT interval. Current guidelines also recommend that all patients with congenital LQTS (symptomatic or asymptomatic) be treated with beta blockers (eg, propanolol, nadolol) to decrease the risk of symptomatic arrhythmias and sudden cardiac death (Choice E).

(Choice A) Diltiazem is commonly used to treat supraventricular tachycardias. It has no role in the management of patients with LQTS.

(Choice B) Disopyramide is a class la antiarrhythmic agent that can cause further prolongation of the QT interval.

(Choice C) An implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) is recommended for patients with LQTS who have syncope (especially if recurrent) or ventricular tachycardia (eg, torsade de pointes) on beta blocker therapy. ICDs may be considered in patients with a strong family history of sudden cardiac death. However, a beta blocker should be used as initial treatment for this patient, particularly given the risks associated with ICD placement (infection, lead fracture). ICDs are also used as secondary prevention in patients with an aborted cardiac arrest.

Educational objective:
Beta blockers are recommended for patients with congenital long QT syndrome to reduce the risk of symptomatic arrhythmias and sudden cardiac death. An implantable cardioverter-defibrillator is recommended for patients with syncope (especially if recurrent) or ventricular tachycardia (eg, torsade de pointes) on beta blocker therapy or for those with aborted cardiac arrest.

stem: A 67-year-old man comes to the office for routine follow-up. He has a history of hypertension, osteoarthritis, and chronic aortic regurgitation. He reports that he is doing well overall and plays doubles tennis three times a week for exercise, which he does without any chest pain or pressure. He denies shortness of breath, orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, or edema. His medications include aspirin, nebivolol, simvastatin, chlorthalidone, and acetaminophen. His blood pressure is 128/60 mm Hg and pulse is 67/min. His BMI is 27 kg/m². Cardiovascular examination reveals a normal S1 and S2. There is 2/6 mid-systolic murmur at the right upper sternal border followed by a high-pitched diastolic decrescendo murmur best heard at the left upper sternal border. The intensity of the diastolic murmur is increased with handgrip. His peripheral pulses are 3+ bilaterally. A transthoracic echocardiogram demonstrates normal left ventricular size and function. The aortic valve is calcified and demonstrates mild stenosis (mean gradient = 13 mm Hg) with moderate aortic regurgitation. When compared to the echocardiogram from two years ago, both the aortic stenosis and regurgitation are worse. Which of the following would be the most appropriate next step?
explanation:
This patient presents with asymptomatic mixed aortic valve disease, predominantly moderate aortic regurgitation (AR) seen on echocardiography (ECHO). Current guidelines recommend isolated aortic valve replacement for severe AR in symptomatic patients (i.e., shortness of breath, decreased exercise tolerance) and asymptomatic patients with abnormal ECHO findings (e.g.. ejection fraction < 50% or a dilated left ventricle with either end-diastolic size > 75 mm or end-systolic size > 55 mm). Vasodilators (ACEI or nifedipine) are indicated for severe AR in symptomatic patients with left ventricular (LV) dysfunction who are not surgical candidates for valve replacement. Symptomatic patients awaiting surgery should receive intense medical therapy with digoxin, diuretics, and vasodilators to help decrease congestive symptoms prior to surgery. Patients who do not meet surgical or medical therapy criteria need re-evaluation for symptoms and a repeat echocardiogram in 6-12 months. Patients with mild AR and normal LV function need only a yearly clinical evaluation and repeat ECHO every 2-3 years. There are no formal guidelines for patients with moderate AR, but most clinicians would re-evaluate the patient clinically every 6-12 months with repeat ECHO at each visit as clinically indicated (especially in patients who show progressive disease, such as this one).

(Choice A) This patient only has moderate regurgitation and mild stenosis. Even if the valvular disease were severe, he does not meet any current criteria for valve replacement (i.e., symptomatic, dilatation, or LV dysfunction).

(Choice B) Coronary angiography would only be needed if the patient were having symptoms of ischemic heart disease, or if the noninvasive tests were inconclusive to determine the valve severity. Coronary angiography is also needed prior to valve surgery to determine if coronary revascularization is required simultaneously.

(Choice C) Lisinopril, an ACEI, is also a vasodilator that can be helpful for patients with decompensated heart failure from aortic regurgitation. However, they are not indicated for the long-term management of asymptomatic patients with mild to moderate aortic regurgitation and normal systolic function (such as this patient).

(Choice E) Transesophageal echocardiograms (TEE) can be useful to get more detailed images of the left-sided valves in instances such as endocarditis or prosthetic valve dysfunction. They are rarely better than transthoracic echocardiograms (TTE) for estimating valve severity in native valves.

Educational objective:
Valve replacement in patients with chronic severe aortic regurgitation should be considered based upon the development of symptoms or left ventricular dilatation/dysfunction. In the absence of those findings, close clinical follow up and echocardiograms every 6-12 months are warranted.
