A 32-year-old man with known hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is brought to the emergency department after an episode of syncope. He was carrying groceries to his car when he suddenly passed out. He had no chest pain, lightheadedness, nausea, or palpitations prior to the event. The patient now says he feels fine and wants to go home. He was diagnosed with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy 2 years ago. He had a mild provokable left ventricular outflow tract gradient with exercise due to systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve. The gradient was eliminated with metoprolol. The patient claims compliance with the therapy and has no exertional shortness of breath or chest pain. His paternal uncle died suddenly at age 40.

Blood pressure is 132/80 mm Hg and pulse is 62/min. Fourth heart sound is heard at the apex with the patient in the left lateral decubitus position. Electrocardiogram shows normal sinus rhythm and T-wave inversion in leads 1, V5, and V6; it is unchanged from a previous reading. Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
explanation:
Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) is a relatively common autosomal dominant genetic cardiac disease with a prevalence of 1:500 in the general population. It has heterogeneous and variable clinical presentation, prognosis, and treatment strategies. Most patients with HCM have few or no symptoms and a normal life expectancy. Sudden cardiac death (SCD) is the most dreaded complication, with an annual incidence of approximately 1% of HCM patients. The following features confer a higher risk of SCD in patients with HCM: 

• History of cardiac arrest (or sustained spontaneous ventricular tachycardia) 
• Family history of sudden death 
• Syncope (recurrent and/or associated with exertion) 
• Nonsustained ventricular tachycardia on Holter monitoring 
• Hypotensive blood pressure response to exercise 
• Extreme left ventricular hypertrophy (>3 cm maximum septal wall thickness) 

An implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) is indicated for both primary and secondary prevention of SCD in patients with 21 major high-risk features. This patient has a history of syncope and a family history of sudden death and should be referred for ICD placement for primary prevention of SCD. 

(Choice A) Disopyramide is a negative inotropic agent that can be used to alleviate left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) gradient in patients with symptomatic obstructive HCM. It has no role in primary prevention of SCD. This patient had mild LVOT gradient on exercise that was eliminated with the use of metoprolol. There is no indication for additional therapy with disopyramide at this time.

(Choice B) Electrophysiology testing has not been shown to be a reliable predictor of SCD in patients with HCM. It should not be used for risk stratification prior to ICD therapy.

(Choice D) Therapy with beta blockers is indicated in symptomatic patients with heart failure and/or LVOT obstruction. This patient had effective reduction in gradient with metoprolol, and additional therapy with metoprolol is not indicated given his heart rate of 62/min.

(Choice E) Tilt-table testing is indicated in patients with recurrent episodes of syncope in the absence of organic heart disease. This patient has a known history of HCM with high-risk features and should have an ICD placed for primary prevention of SCD.

Educational objective:
The major high-risk features that increase risk of sudden cardiac death (SCD) in patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy include family history of sudden death, recurrent or exertional syncope, nonsustained ventricular tachycardia on Holter monitoring, hypotensive response during exercise, and massive left ventricular hypertrophy >3 cm. Patients with ≥1 high-risk features should have an implantable cardioverter- defibrillator for the primary prevention of SCD.

A 60-year-old man comes to the physician complaining of occasional episodes of dizziness, usually when he tries to get up quickly. He had sustained an anterior wall myocardial infarction 4 months ago, and had emergent percutaneous revascularization of his proximal left anterior descending artery with placement of a stent. He denies any chest pain, shortness of breath, palpitations, or syncope. He has been able to resume walking about 3 miles every day. His home medications include aspirin, clopidogrel, rosuvastatin, carvedilol, valsartan, and spironolactone. Echocardiography performed 1 week ago showed a large area of dyskinesia in the anterior and anterolateral myocardial segments, with an ejection fraction of 25%. There was also mild mitral and tricuspid regurgitation present.

His blood pressure is 112/62 mm Hg and pulse is 68/min. A soft, 2/6 holosystolic murmur is heard at the cardiac apex in the left lateral position. Lungs are clear to auscultation. His ECG in the office shows sinus rhythm and Q waves in precordial leads. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
explanation:
Current guidelines recommend ICD therapy for primary prevention of sudden cardiac death in patients with myocardial infarction (MI) with persistent LVEF < 30% (or < 35% along with NYHA class II or III symptoms), who are at least 40 days post-MI and 3 months status-post CABG/percutaneous coronary intervention (if performed). This patient's MI was treated with percutaneous revascularization 4 months ago, and he is on optimal medical therapy. He has persistent left ventricular dysfunction with an ejection fraction of 25%. The most appropriate next step is to counsel and offer him ICD placement for primary prevention of sudden cardiac death.

(Choice A) Long-term event monitor is indicated to evaluate for arrhythmias causing palpitations or syncope. This patient's dizziness is likely due to orthostatic hypotension, but he also meets criteria for ICD implantation.

(Choice B) Amiodarone is effective for preventing recurrent ventricular arrhythmia in patients with prior myocardial infarction and low ejection fraction. However, its use has not been shown to improve long-term mortality in this patient's setting and is usually not recommended.

(Choice C) Electrophysiological study (EPS) is reserved for patients with an ejection fraction of 35-40%, prior MI, and documented non-sustained VT on Holter monitoring. Inducible ventricular fibrillation or sustained ventricular tachycardia on EPS is an indication for ICD implantation for primary prevention. However, this patient already meets criteria for ICD placement and does not need further evaluation.

(Choice E) Submaximal exercise testing can help risk stratify coronary artery disease patients and assess exercise capacity in heart failure patients awaiting cardiac transplantation. This patient is able to walk 3 miles every day and would likely not benefit from exercise testing.

Educational objective:
ICD therapy for primary prevention of sudden cardiac death is recommended in patients with persistent LVEF ≤ 30% (or ≤35% along with NYHA class II or III symptoms) due to prior MI, who are at least 40 days post myocardial infarction and 3 months status-post percutaneous coronary intervention or CABG (if performed).

A 72-year-old man comes to the office 4 weeks following discharge from the hospital due to an episode of acute decompensated congestive heart failure. The patient feels much better now but claims that he gets tired easily. He becomes short of breath after walking a few blocks on a level surface. He has a history of myocardial infarction, coronary artery bypass grafting, ischemic cardiomyopathy, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. The patient has had several hospital admissions for decompensated heart failure over the past 2 years. His home medications include aspirin 81 mg/day, carvedilol 25 mg twice a day, quinapril 40 mg/day, atorvastatin 40 mg/day, furosemide 40 mg/day, and long- acting insulin. Temperature is 37.2 C (99 F), blood pressure is 128/76 mm Hg, pulse is 76/min, and respirations are 16/min. Pulse oximetry is 94% on room air. The patient is in no apparent respiratory distress. Jugular venous pressure is measured at 8 cm H2O. Lung examination reveals clear lung fields with decreased breath sounds at the bases. Cardiac examination reveals normal S1 and S2 along with a 2/6 holosystolic murmur heard over the cardiac apex. There is minimal pitting edema around the ankles.

Laboratory results are as follows:

Complete blood count
Hemoglobin: 12.5 g/dL

Serum chemistry
Potassium: 3.9 mEq/L
Creatinine: 1.8 mg/dL

ECG is shown in this image. A recent echocardiogram showed a mildly dilated left ventricular cavity with akinesis of the anterior and anteroseptal walls as well as a left ventricular ejection fraction of 30%. Which of the following additional treatments would most benefit this patient?
explanation:
This patient has severe left ventricular systolic dysfunction due to prior myocardial infarction with New York Heart Association (NYHA) class II symptoms at baseline. The addition of an aldosterone antagonist (eg, spironolactone, eplerenone) to optimal therapy (beta blocker, ACE inhibitor) has been shown to reduce morbidity and mortality in patients with symptomatic heart failure with a left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) ≤35%. Aldosterone antagonists should be avoided in patients with significant renal disease (creatinine clearance <30 mL/min) or in patients with hyperkalemia (serum potassium >5 mEq/L). Patients receiving aldosterone antagonists should undergo serial monitoring of serum potassium and renal function.

(Choice A) Cardiac resynchronization therapy with biventricular pacing is recommended in patients in sinus rhythm who have persistent symptoms despite optimal medical therapy, an LVEF ≤35%, a QRS duration 150 msec, and a left bundle branch block. This patient's ECG shows a narrow QRS complex with a duration <120 msec, and biventricular pacing is not indicated at this time.

(Choice B) Digoxin is used as an adjunctive therapy in patients with systolic dysfunction with heart failure who continue to have symptoms despite adequate therapy with an ACE inhibitor, beta blocker, aldosterone antagonist, and diuretics. Digoxin reduces the rate of hospitalization for heart failure, but it has not been shown to improve overall survival. This patient should be started on an aldosterone antagonist first; if he still has symptoms, digoxin could be considered.

(Choice C) Combination therapy with hydralazine and oral nitrates with optimal therapy (eg, beta blocker, ACE inhibitor, aldosterone antagonist if indicated) improves symptoms and survival in select patients (eg, African Americans with NYHA classes III-IV heart failure) with systolic dysfunction. Its use is also recommended in patients who are intolerant of ACE inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers, or who have persistent symptoms despite optimal therapy.

(Choice D) Metolazone is a thiazide diuretic that is usually given to patients with peripheral edema (volume overload) refractory to loop diuretics (eg, furosemide). However, this patient has minimal peripheral edema/volume overload and likely would not benefit from metolazone.

Educational objective:
Optimal medical therapy in patients with heart failure due to left ventricular systolic dysfunction includes diuretics, a beta blocker, an ACE inhibitor, and an aldosterone antagonist. Digoxin and a combination of hydralazine and oral nitrates can be used in symptomatic patients despite optimal medical therapy. Cardiac resynchronization therapy with biventricular pacing is recommended in patients in sinus rhythm who have persistent symptoms despite optimal medical therapy, a left ventricular ejection fraction ≤35%, a QRS duration ≥150 msec, and a left bundle branch block.

stem: A 29-year-old woman who immigrated to the United States from India comes to the office to establish care. She has a mild sore throat that she believes may have come from her toddler, who recently had a fever. The patient has no other concerns. She has a history of gestational diabetes during her 2 pregnancies. In childhood, the patient had a febrile illness associated with loss of motor control. She takes no medications and does not use tobacco or alcohol. Temperature is 36.7 C (98.1 F), blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg, pulse is 70/min, and respirations are 14/min. Examination shows mild erythema of the nasal mucosa and posterior pharynx. Jugular venous pulsation is normal and there is no cervical lymphadenopathy. The lungs are clear. There is a low-pitched diastolic murmur with presystolic accentuation at the apex. Neurologic examination is normal. She is referred for transthoracic echocardiography that shows normal left ventricular function with moderate left atrial enlargement and doming of the mitral valve leaflets in diastole. The estimated mitral valve area is 1.7 cm. There is mild mitral regurgitation. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation regarding antibiotic therapy in this patient?
choice_a: Advise oral amoxicillin prior to dental procedures
choice_b: Check antistreptococcal antibody titers to guide therapy
choice_c: Explain that no antibiotic therapy is indicated
choice_d: Initiate penicillin G benzathine injection every 4 weeks
choice_e: Prescribe oral penicillin V potassium for 10 days for sore throat
explanation:
This patient's childhood history of a febrile illness with movement disorder (chorea) is consistent with previous rheumatic fever complicated by persistent valvular disease (mitral stenosis). Rheumatic fever occurs as a complication of group A beta-hemolytic Streptococcus (GAS) pharyngitis; the initial acute disease and recurrences can be characterized by fever, arthritis, chorea, and heart failure. This patient's current presentation is not consistent with rheumatic fever recurrence; however, the sore throat raises suspicion for GAS pharyngitis. With repeated exposure to GAS, patients with prior rheumatic fever are at high risk for recurrent rheumatic fever and consequent progression of rheumatic heart disease. Therefore, they should receive continuous antibiotic prophylaxis to prevent GAS pharyngitis. Long-acting penicillin G benzathine given intramuscularly every 3-4 weeks is the preferred approach for secondary prevention of rheumatic fever recurrence, and the duration of antibiotic prophylaxis depends on the severity of underlying rheumatic heart disease (presence or absence of carditis and valvular disease). The first dose of intramuscular penicillin would also treat any current GAS colonization/infection. Regardless of whether this patient was previously on antibiotics for rheumatic fever, she should receive an intramuscular dose of penicillin now and should be on continuous antibiotic prophylaxis until age 40 (given her valvular disease).

(Choice A) Antibiotic prophylaxis to lower the risk of infective endocarditis is indicated prior to dental procedures in only patients with the highest-risk cardiac conditions. It is not indicated for rheumatic disease of a native heart valve.

(Choice B) Antistreptococcal antibody titers can be helpful in the initial diagnosis of rheumatic fever, but do not play a role in guiding antibiotic prophylaxis for secondary prevention.

(Choice C) This patient is at risk for further heart damage with recurrent GAS infection, and long-term antibiotic prophylaxis is indicated. Recommending no antibiotic therapy is not appropriate.

(Choice E) Oral penicillin V potassium is an acceptable treatment option for acute GAS pharyngitis (primary prevention of rheumatic fever). It is also an alternate treatment for secondary prevention of rheumatic fever recurrence; however, due to increased failure rates with orally administered antibiotics, intramuscular penicillin G is preferred.

Educational objective:
Patients with rheumatic fever should receive continuous antibiotic prophylaxis to prevent recurrent GAS pharyngitis and limit the risk of progression of rheumatic heart disease. Intramuscular penicillin G benzathine every 3-4 weeks is preferred, and the duration of therapy is determined by the severity of underlying rheumatic heart disease (presence or absence of carditis and valvular disease).

A 22-year-old man comes to the office due to 6 months of exertional shortness of breath. He describes himself as nonathletic and has never engaged in competitive sports. The patient has recently experienced dyspnea on moderate exertion. He also describes a pounding sensation in his head at night. He does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs.

Blood pressure is 150/65 mm Hg and pulse is 90/min. No jugular venous distension is present. There is no digital clubbing or cyanosis. The apical impulse is brisk and displaced to the left. A 2/6 continuous murmur is heard below the left clavicle. Upper and lower extremity pulses are prominent and equal. The lungs are clear on auscultation. If untreated, this patient's risk for which of the following is most increased?
explanation:
This patient most likely has an unrepaired patent ductus arteriosus (PDA); the prevalence of PDA is increasing due to improved survival rates of premature infants. Small PDAs are typically asymptomatic and may be detected incidentally due to a continuous murmur in the left infraclavicular region. Moderate-sized PDAs often present later with dyspnea and exercise intolerance due to LV failure: wide pulse pressure, bounding pulses, and a laterally displaced apical impulse are characteristically present. With a large PDA, left-to-right shunting typically leads to left ventricular (LV) volume overload (ie, high- output heart failure) in infancy or early childhood, and if untreated can progress to pulmonary hypertension and Eisenmenger syndrome (right-to-left shunting). Patients with unrepaired PDA are at increased risk for infective endarteritis (PDA-related endocarditis), especially if there is associated pulmonary hypertension. Vegetations typically affect the pulmonary end of the PDA and lead to septic pulmonary emboli. PDA closure may be considered in patients who have had PDA-related endocarditis. Procedural antibiotic prophylaxis is recommended for unrepaired PDA if it is complicated by Eisenmenger syndrome or cyanotic pulmonary hypertension. Prophylaxis is also recommended within 6 months after surgical repair with prosthetic material or if there is a residual defect after surgery.

(Choices A and D) Congenital coarctation of the aorta increases the risk of both aortic dissection and intracranial aneurysm. Patients typically have upper body hypertension and decreased blood flow to the lower extremities. Headaches and epistaxis may be present, and a continuous murmur is common; however, the equal upper and lower extremity pulses in this patient make this diagnosis unlikely.

(Choice B) Constrictive pericarditis can occur due to viral pericarditis, radiation therapy, or tuberculosis, but it is not associated with PDA.

(Choice E) Mitral stenosis most commonly occurs due to rheumatic fever. PDA does not carry a significant association with mitral stenosis.

Educational objective:
Symptomatic patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) characteristically presents with left ventricular failure accompanied by a continuous murmur, wide pulse pressure, and bounding pulses. Pulmonary hypertension, and in severe cases Eisenmenger syndrome, can also occur. Unrepaired PDA increases the risk of infective endarteritis that typically affects the pulmonary end of the PDA.

A 35-year-old woman comes to the office as she missed her period 10 days ago and believes that she may be pregnant. She otherwise has regular monthly menstrual cycles. The patient moved to the United States from South Africa 6 months ago, and has a history of rheumatic heart disease. She had a "ministroke" 8 years ago and was found to be in atrial fibrillation at that time; she has since been on warfarin for anticoagulation. The patient took antibiotic prophylaxis for secondary prevention of rheumatic fever with intramuscular penicillin until age 30.

Temperature is 37.2 C (99 F), blood pressure is 122/82 mm Hg, pulse is 96/min, and respirations are 14/min. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination reveals irregular heart sounds, an accentuated S1, and a loud "snapping" sound shortly after S2. There is also a faint mid-diastolic murmur heard over the cardiac apex.

Urine pregnancy test is positive. ECG is shown in the exhibit. Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
choice_a: Continue warfarin with close INR monitoring throughout pregnancy
choice_b: Stop warfarin and monitor closely throughout pregnancy
choice_c: Stop warfarin and start daily dabigatran
choice_d: Stop warfarin and start daily subcutaneous unfractionated heparin
choice_e: Stop warfarin and start subcutaneous low-molecular-weight heparin
explanation:
This patient, who has a history of rheumatic heart disease and physical examination findings of an accentuated S1, a loud "snapping" sound after S2 (opening snap), and a mid-diastolic murmur, has rheumatic mitral stenosis. Atrial fibrillation in the setting of mitral stenosis is associated with high thromboembolic risk, and this patient should continue anticoagulation therapy throughout pregnancy. Low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH) is recommended in such patients until the final few weeks of pregnancy, at which time therapy is often transitioned to unfractionated heparin (UFH) for easier reversibility during labor and delivery. Both LMWH and UFH are not associated with teratogenicity and do not cross the placental barrier to cause fetal anticoagulation.

(Choice A) Warfarin is associated with teratogenicity (eg, skeletal abnormalities) and can cross the placental barrier, leading to fetal bleeding. Low-dose warfarin ≤5 mg/day appears to provide a higher safety margin, and continuing this regimen throughout pregnancy (including the first trimester) is a potential option for pregnant patients with mechanical heart valves. However, pregnant patients with any other indication for anticoagulation (eg, atrial fibrillation, venous thromboembolism) and those with higher dose requirements (>5 mg/day) should be managed with subcutaneous LMWH.

(Choice B) This patient is at high risk for systemic thromboembolism during pregnancy and requires anticoagulation. Monitoring without anticoagulation would not be appropriate.

(Choice C) Oral direct thrombin inhibitors (eg, dabigatran) and factor Xa inhibitors (eg, apixaban, rivaroxaban, edoxaban) are not indicated in patients with valvular atrial fibrillation. Furthermore, these drugs do not have adequate safety and efficacy information for use during pregnancy.

(Choice D) Subcutaneous UFH every 12 hours (not daily) is indicated for anticoagulation during pregnancy in patients with severe renal insufficiency (creatinine clearance < 30 mg/mL). However, when possible, the use of LMWH is preferred due to the lower risk of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia.

Educational objective:
Warfarin can cross the placental barrier and is associated with fetal bleeding and risk of teratogenicity when used during pregnancy. With the possible exception of patients on low-dose warfarin for a mechanical heart valve, all others who require anticoagulation during pregnancy should be switched to low-molecular- weight or unfractionated heparin.

A 22-year-old African American man is evaluated for an abnormal ECG obtained at a health fair. He has no complaints and says that he has been healthy all his life. He runs 6-8 miles a day and plays basketball for several hours every weekend. The patient has no symptoms during physical activity. His paternal uncle suffered from diabetes mellitus and died of a heart attack at age 50. His mother had a minor stroke at age 40.

Examination shows a muscular, well-built man. His blood pressure is 132/90 mm Hg on the right arm and 137/85 mm Hg on the left. His pulse is 54/min. Lungs are clear on auscultation, he has normal first and second heart sounds, and peripheral pulses are full and symmetric. ECG shows high voltage in precordial leads and downsloping ST-segment depression with T-wave inversion in leads V4-V6. An echocardiogram shows left ventricular hypertrophy with septal thickness of 18 mm and posterior wall thickness of 12 mm (normal ≤10 mm). There is no valvular disease, systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve, or left ventricular outflow tract gradient at rest or with Valsalva maneuver. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM), an autosomal dominant genetic disease. Depending on the degree of hypertrophy and left ventricular outflow obstruction, patients with HCM may have no symptoms at all or severe symptoms (eg, dyspnea, fatigue, chest pain, palpitations, and syncope). HCM must be distinguished from other causes of left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH). The diagnosis of HCM is generally suspected by evidence of LVH on ECG and confirmed by echocardiography. ECG often shows prominent Q waves in inferior and lateral leads, representing septal depolarization. The diagnostic criterion of HCM is LV wall thickness of 215 mm (anywhere in the LV wall) that is not readily explained by another cause (eg, hypertension and aortic stenosis). The degree and distribution of hypertrophy in HCM can be quite variable and include asymmetric septal, apical, left ventricular free wall, or concentric hypertrophy. This patient's LV septal wall thickness of 18 mm is consistent with HCM (regardless of the posterior wall thickness of 12 mm).

(Choice A) Athlete's heart is a term describing the physiologic increase in left ventricular wall thickness, cavity size, and mass that occurs in response to intense endurance training or exercise. In athlete's heart, LVH is generally symmetric and ≤12 mm. By contrast, in patients with HCM, LVH is frequently asymmetric (as seen in this patient) and wall thickness is ≥15 mm. ECG can show increased QRS voltage in both athlete's heart and HCM; however, Q waves and T wave inversions (as seen in this patient) are more consistent with HCM. Sinus bradycardia at rest is a common feature in well-trained endurance athletes and is due to increased vagal tone induced by exercise conditioning. It will not help differentiate HCM from athlete's heart.

(Choice B) Coronary artery anomalies are not associated with LVH. They are usually asymptomatic or can cause exertional angina due to compression of an anomalous coronary artery coursing between the aortic root and main pulmonary trunk.

(Choice C) This patient has no history or evidence of severe hypertension. The increase in wall thickness in LVH due to hypertension is generally symmetric and usually <15 mm.

(Choice E) Cardiac sarcoidosis commonly presents with conduction abnormalities, including heart block, ventricular arrhythmias, and heart failure, due to systolic or diastolic dysfunction. Severe LVH is not seen with cardiac sarcoidosis.

Educational objective:
Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) is an autosomal dominant genetic disorder characterized by left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH) of variable morphology. In HCM, LVH is frequently asymmetric and wall thickness is ≥15 mm; in individuals with athlete's heart, it is generally symmetric and wall thickness is ≤12 mm.

stem: A 46-year-old man comes to the emergency department after awakening with dyspnea and diaphoresis this morning. He has had 6 weeks of fever, increased weakness, and fatigue. The patient underwent a root canal procedure 4 months ago but reports that he has been otherwise healthy. He has no history of cardiovascular disease, pulmonary disease, or cardiac surgery. Temperature is 38.4 C (101.1 F), blood pressure is 144/76 mm Hg. pulse is 106/min, and respirations are 28/min. The patient is diaphoretic and appears uncomfortable. There are no skin rashes. The pupils are equal, round, and reactive without conjunctival lesions or suffusion. There is no neck stiffness or meningeal signs. A short, early diastolic murmur is heard at the left sternal border. Coarse inspiratory crackles are heard bilaterally halfway up the lung fields. The spleen is not palpable. His speech is abnormal. Chest x-ray reveals pulmonary congestion. Transthoracic echocardiogram shows a 7-mm, mobile echodensity on the aortic valve with high-grade aortic regurgitation. MRI of the brain reveals a small area of acute infarction in the left frontal lobe. Blood cultures are obtained and empiric antibiotics are initiated. Noninvasive positive-pressure ventilation is started with some improvement in respiratory distress. Which of the following is an indication for cardiac valve surgery in this patient?
explanation:
This patient has developed subacute infective endocarditis (IE) likely due to bacteremia at the time of his recent root canal procedure. Medical management with long-term intravenous antibiotics is often successful in treating IE; however, early surgical intervention (ie, valvular repair or replacement prior to the completion of a full antibiotic course) is sometimes required. Vegetations in IE can impair valve leaflet coaptation and lead to valvular regurgitation and heart failure. Acute heart failure due to IE has a >90% mortality rate, which is reduced to 75% with medical therapy and 25% with surgical intervention. Therefore, signs of acute heart failure (eg, pulmonary edema) are a strong indication for early surgical intervention for IE.

(Choice A) The location of IE alone (eg, aortic valve, mitral valve) does not indicate the need for surgery.

(Choice B) This patient's brain MRI findings are with consistent with an acute septic embolic stroke that occurred prior to the initiation of antibiotics. This is not an indication for valvular surgery as the risk of septic embolization usually decreases rapidly once antibiotics are initiated. However, a systemic embolic event while on appropriate antibiotics would warrant surgical intervention.

(Choice C) The cardiovascular system may be able to compensate for gradually developed valvular regurgitation. Therefore, echocardiographic evidence of high-grade valvular regurgitation alone is not an indication for surgery unless it causes acute heart failure.

(Choice E) Large vegetation size may increase the likelihood of septic embolization. Current guidelines recommend early surgical intervention for a mobile aortic or mitral valve vegetation >10 mm in the setting of a prior systemic embolic event. This patient's 7-mm aortic valve vegetation in the setting of a prior systemic embolic event is not an indication for early surgical intervention.

Educational objective:
Early surgical intervention is sometimes required in the management of infective endocarditis. Valvular regurgitation complicated by acute heart failure is a strong indication for early valvular repair or replacement. Other surgical indications include uncontrollable infection and embolic complications while on appropriate antibiotics.

stem:
A 55-year-old man comes to the physician complaining of an episode of rectal bleeding. His past medical history includes chronic constipation for which he takes over-the-counter laxatives. He also has a history of intravenous drug use and an episode of tricuspid and mitral valve infective endocarditis 15 years ago. Since that episode, he has stopped using illicit drugs. The patient has a 20-pack-year smoking history and drinks 1-2 cans of beer daily. Family history is not significant. He is allergic to penicillin.

His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Stool is positive for occult blood.

The patient is scheduled for a colonoscopy.

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
explanation:
This patient has a history of infective endocarditis (IE), which places him at high risk for developing a recurrent episode. However, current guidelines do not recommend routine antibiotic prophylaxis for the prevention of IE in patients undergoing gastrointestinal (eg, colonoscopy) or genitourinary procedures (eg, cystoscopy), even in those at high risk for IE. Antibiotic prophylaxis should be considered only for patients with the highest-risk cardiac conditions (eg, prosthetic heart valves, prior history of IE, unrepaired cyanotic congenital heart disease) who are undergoing dental procedures involving manipulation of the gingival tissue or the periapical region of the teeth or perforation of the oral mucosa. If a high-risk patient undergoing a GI or GU procedure has an active infection (eg, enterococcal urinary tract infection), then antibiotic therapy directed at the offending organism is indicated. This patient is currently asymptomatic and should proceed with colonoscopy without antibiotic prophylaxis.

(Choices A, B, and E) Antibiotic prophylaxis is not indicated prior to colonoscopy in this patient.

(Choice C) Routine echocardiography prior to procedures is not indicated in patients without new or worsening cardiac symptoms (eg, dyspnea, chest pain).

Educational objective:
Antibiotic prophylaxis for the prevention of infective endocarditis is not recommended for patients undergoing gastrointestinal or genitourinary procedures, even in those at high risk (eg, prior history of infective endocarditis). Prophylaxis is reserved for patients with the highest-risk cardiac conditions undergoing high-risk dental procedures.

stem: A 74-year-old man is hospitalized for an episode of acute decompensated heart failure. He was treated with intravenous loop diuretics and responded with significant diuresis. The patient has a history of nonischemic cardiomyopathy with a left ventricular ejection fraction of 25%, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. His medications include lisinopril, carvedilol, and atorvastatin. Blood pressure is 106/62 mm Hg and pulse is 62/min. A 24-hour holter monitor performed during the hospitalization showed approximately 4,000 premature ventricular contractions and several episodes of non-sustained ventricular tachycardia (up to 4-5 beats). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of the holter monitor findings?
explanation:
Nonsustained ventricular tachycardia (NSVT) is common in patients with heart failure and systolic dysfunction, and its frequency and duration increase with the severity of the disease. In patients with nonischemic cardiomyopathy, NSVT has not been clearly shown to be a predictor of sudden cardiac death. As a result, in the absence of symptoms (eg, palpitations, syncope), specific antiarrhythmic therapy for NSVT is not indicated. These patients should instead be treated with optimal medical therapy for heart failure (eg, beta blockers, ACE inhibitors, aldosterone antagonists). Routine suppression of NSVT with antiarrhythmic drugs has not been shown to improve survival and may even increase mortality.

(Choices A, B, and C) Antiarrhythmic therapy with drugs such as amiodarone, mexiletine, or sotalol is not indicated for asymptomatic NSVT in this patient.

(Choice D) An implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) is recommended for primary prevention of sudden cardiac death in patients with symptomatic heart failure and an ejection fraction ≤35% (NYHA class II or III) or an ejection fraction ≤30% (NYHA class I) who have a life expectancy of >1 year. This patient has nonischemic cardiomyopathy and should be treated with optimal medical therapy for at least 3-6 months before being considered for ICD placement. In patients with ischemic cardiomyopathy, an ICD is recommended at least 40 days after a myocardial infarction.

Educational objective:
Nonsustained ventricular tachycardia (NSVT) is common in patients with heart failure and systolic dysfunction. In the absence of symptoms, specific antiarrhythmic therapy for NSVT is not indicated. Treatment should focus on optimal medical therapy for the underlying heart failure.

stem: A 56-year-old man comes to the physician for an initial visit. He was recently diagnosed with hypertension at a health fair and has no other medical problems. He does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. He has a 30-minute daily walking program and follows a healthy diet. His blood pressure in the office today is 154/96 mm Hg. Physical examination, including cardiac auscultation, is unremarkable. Fasting glucose, electrolytes, and renal function are normal. Fasting lipid panel reveals LDL of 140 mg/dL, HDL of 45 mg/dL, and triglycerides of 160 mg/dL. He is started on lisinopril. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
explanation:
This patient has newly diagnosed stage 2 hypertension (blood pressure ≥140/90 mm Hg). According to current guidelines, the goal blood pressure for most patients is <130/80 mm Hg. For patients with stage 2 hypertension, initial therapy with two antihypertensive agents from different classes is often recommended. However, for patients with stage 1 hypertension (130-139/80-89 mm Hg), a single agent is typically started. This patient has been started on lisinopril and should be reassessed in approximately one month to evaluate the response to therapy and monitor for adverse effects (eg, cough, hyperkalemia, creatinine elevation).

(Choice A) While starting two agents is an option for stage 2 hypertension, it is also reasonable to start with one agent and titrate or add a second agent based on the follow-up blood pressure. Since he has already been started on lisinopril, the next step is follow-up.

(Choices B and D) Evaluation for secondary causes of hypertension (eg, pheochromocytoma, renal artery stenosis) is not indicated in the absence of suggestive features such as resistant hypertension, sudden onset, or abdominal bruit.

(Choice C) Routine exercise stress testing is not indicated in asymptomatic patients with newly diagnosed hypertension.

Educational objective:
Patients started on antihypertensive therapy should be reassessed in approximately one month to evaluate the blood pressure response and monitor for potential adverse effects of the medication.

stem: A 68-year-old man with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia comes to the emergency department with sudden-onset, severe chest pain that radiates to his back. The pain is described as 'tearing' and began 30 minutes ago. On physical examination, his blood pressure is 190/110 mm Hg in the right arm and 160/90 mm Hg in the left arm. He has a 3/6 diastolic decrescendo murmur at the right sternal border. His lungs are clear. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
explanation:
This patient's presentation (sudden-onset tearing chest pain radiating to the back, blood pressure discrepancy, and a new aortic regurgitation murmur) is highly suggestive of an acute Type A aortic dissection. Type A dissections involve the ascending aorta and are a surgical emergency. The initial management focus for all patients with suspected aortic dissection is to reduce heart rate and blood pressure to limit the shear stress on the aortic wall. Intravenous beta blockers (eg, labetalol, esmolol) are first-line therapy to achieve a target heart rate of <60/min and a systolic blood pressure between 100-120 mm Hg.

(Choice A) Aspirin and heparin are indicated for acute coronary syndromes but should be avoided in patients with suspected aortic dissection as they can worsen bleeding into the false lumen.

(Choice B) CT angiography is an excellent diagnostic tool for aortic dissection, but initial stabilization of heart rate and blood pressure is the priority.

(Choice D) While Type A dissection requires emergent surgery, stabilization must be initiated first.

(Choice E) Transthoracic echocardiogram has limited sensitivity for detecting aortic dissection compared to TEE or CT angiography.

Educational objective:
The initial management of acute aortic dissection involves rapid reduction of heart rate and blood pressure using intravenous beta blockers to minimize aortic wall shear stress.

stem: A 42-year-old man comes to the office for follow-up of palpitations. He reports feeling a 'skipping' or 'thumping' sensation in his chest several times a day. He has no chest pain, shortness of breath, or syncope. He drinks 2-3 cups of coffee daily and does not smoke. Physical examination is unremarkable. An ECG shows normal sinus rhythm with occasional premature ventricular contractions (PVCs). A 24-hour Holter monitor shows a total of 500 PVCs in 24 hours. Echocardiogram shows normal cardiac structure and function. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
explanation:
Premature ventricular contractions (PVCs) are common and often benign in patients with no structural heart disease. For asymptomatic or minimally symptomatic patients with a low PVC burden and normal echocardiogram, no specific treatment is required other than reassurance and avoidance of triggers (eg, caffeine, tobacco, stress). If symptoms are significantly bothersome, beta blockers or calcium channel blockers can be used as first-line therapy.

(Choice A) Amiodarone has a significant side effect profile and is not indicated for the management of benign PVCs.

(Choice B) Electrophysiological studies are not indicated for low-burden, asymptomatic PVCs.

(Choice C) Metoprolol is a treatment option if symptoms are distressing, but reassurance is the most appropriate initial step for mild symptoms.

(Choice D) Radiofrequency ablation is reserved for patients with a very high PVC burden (usually >10-15% of total beats) that leads to PVC-induced cardiomyopathy or for those who remain highly symptomatic despite medical therapy.

Educational objective:
In patients with no structural heart disease and a low burden of premature ventricular contractions, reassurance and avoidance of triggers are the most appropriate management steps.

stem: A 65-year-old man with a history of hypertension and a 40-pack-year smoking history comes for a routine visit. He has no symptoms. His blood pressure is 138/84 mm Hg. According to the United States Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) guidelines, which of the following screening tests should be performed?
explanation:
The USPSTF recommends a one-time screening for abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) with ultrasonography in men aged 65 to 75 who have ever smoked (defined as ≥100 cigarettes in their lifetime). Screening is not routinely recommended for men who have never smoked or for women.

(Choice A) Screening for carotid artery stenosis in asymptomatic adults is not recommended.

(Choice B) While annual screening for lung cancer with low-dose CT is recommended for certain smokers, this patient's age and smoking history need to meet specific criteria (age 50-80 and ≥20 pack-year history).

(Choice C) Exercise stress testing is not recommended for screening asymptomatic adults for coronary artery disease.

(Choice E) Routine echocardiography is not recommended for screening asymptomatic adults.

Educational objective:
Men aged 65 to 75 who have ever smoked should undergo a one-time screening for abdominal aortic aneurysm with ultrasonography.

stem: A 32-year-old woman at 28 weeks gestation comes to the emergency department with sudden-onset palpitations and lightheadedness. She has no chest pain or shortness of breath. Her blood pressure is 105/65 mm Hg and heart rate is 180/min and regular. The ECG shows a narrow-complex supraventricular tachycardia with no visible P waves. Vagal maneuvers are unsuccessful. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
explanation:
The management of supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) in pregnancy is similar to that in non-pregnant patients. Vagal maneuvers are the initial step. If unsuccessful, intravenous adenosine is the first-line pharmacologic agent. Adenosine is safe in pregnancy as it has a very short half-life and does not cross the placenta in significant amounts.

(Choice B) Amiodarone should be avoided in pregnancy if possible due to the risk of fetal thyroid dysfunction and other potential toxicities.

(Choices C and D) Diltiazem and metoprolol can be used for rate control or termination of SVT if adenosine is unsuccessful, but adenosine is the preferred first-line agent for acute termination.

(Choice E) Synchronized cardioversion is indicated for SVT in pregnancy if the patient is hemodynamically unstable or if pharmacologic therapy fails.

Educational objective:
Intravenous adenosine is the first-line pharmacologic treatment for the acute termination of supraventricular tachycardia in pregnant patients who are hemodynamically stable.

stem: A 78-year-old man comes to the office for follow-up of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). The AAA was incidentally discovered 2 years ago on a CT scan for kidney stones. At that time, it measured 3.8 cm. A follow-up ultrasound 1 year ago showed the AAA was 4.0 cm. His current ultrasound today shows the AAA is 4.3 cm. He has no abdominal or back pain. His blood pressure is 135/80 mm Hg and he takes lisinopril and atorvastatin. He quit smoking 10 years ago. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
explanation:
The frequency of surveillance for an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) depends on its size. For an AAA measuring 4.0 to 4.9 cm, follow-up with ultrasound or CT every 6 to 12 months is recommended. Surgical or endovascular repair is typically indicated for an AAA ≥5.5 cm in men (≥5.0 cm in women) or for an AAA that is rapidly expanding (≥0.5 cm in 6 months or ≥1.0 cm in a year), even if the patient is asymptomatic.

(Choices A and B) This patient's AAA is 4.3 cm and is not rapidly expanding, so repair is not yet indicated.

(Choice D) A 3-year interval is appropriate for a smaller AAA (eg, 3.0 to 3.9 cm).

(Choice E) While smoking cessation and statin therapy are important, dual antiplatelet therapy is not standard for AAA management.

Educational objective:
Abdominal aortic aneurysms measuring 4.0 to 4.9 cm should be monitored with serial imaging every 6 to 12 months.

stem: A 58-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up of typical atrial flutter. He has been taking metoprolol for rate control, but he continues to experience episodes of palpitations and fatigue. He has no other medical problems. Echocardiogram shows normal heart structure and function. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to restore and maintain sinus rhythm?
explanation:
Radiofrequency ablation has an excellent success rate in restoring and maintaining sinus rhythm in patients with typical atrial flutter. It is generally preferred over long-term antiarrhythmic agents as a safe and effective first-line treatment in such patients.

(Choice A) Adenosine is useful for acute termination of AV nodal reentrant tachycardia. However, it has no role in patients with atrial flutter.

(Choice B) AV nodal blocking agents (i.e., calcium channel blockers, beta-blockers, or digoxin) are frequently used in patients with atrial flutter or fibrillation with rapid ventricular rates. In contrast to atrial fibrillation, typical atrial flutter is relatively difficult to control with pharmacologic agents. Radiofrequency ablation has emerged as a safe and effective first-line treatment option in such patients.

(Choices C and E) Flecainide is a class IC antiarrhythmic agent and is occasionally used to maintain sinus rhythm in patients with paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. Sotalol is a class III antiarrhythmic agent. These drugs have marginal efficacy and a significant side effect profile. They are generally not preferred for restoring or maintaining sinus rhythm in patients with typical atrial flutter.

Educational objective:
Radiofrequency ablation has an excellent success rate in restoring and maintaining sinus rhythm in patients with typical atrial flutter. It is generally preferred over long-term antiarrhythmic agents as a safe and effective first-line treatment in such patients.

A 54-year-old man comes to the physician with chest discomfort. During the last 6 months, the patient has had left-sided chest pain radiating to the left shoulder, which is commonly provoked by exertion but also occurs at rest. The chest pain lasts a few seconds to several minutes, and he can usually "walk it off." Past medical history includes hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and peptic ulcer disease. The patient received a permanent pacemaker 6 years ago after an episode of syncope. His father also had a pacemaker. Current medications include lisinopril, amlodipine, famotidine, and rosuvastatin.

His blood pressure is 111/70 mm Hg and pulse is 67/min. Chest is clear to auscultation. No cardiac murmurs or carotid bruits are appreciated. The abdomen is nontender. Pulses are full and symmetric bilaterally.

Electrocardiogram shows normal sinus rhythm with paced ventricular complexes (atrial sensed, ventricular paced rhythm).

Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
explanation:
The pretest probability of coronary heart disease (CHD) is used to determine the need for noninvasive diagnostic evaluation or coronary angiography in patients with suspected chest pain symptoms. This patient has probable but not classic chest pain and an intermediate pretest probability of CHD (between 20%-80%) based on his age, gender, and symptoms. The next step in management is to perform a noninvasive evaluation with exercise or pharmacologic stress testing. Current guidelines recommend an exercise electrocardiogram (ECG) stress test without imaging as the preferred initial test in most patients with an intermediate pretest probability of CHD as the test also provides useful information about symptoms, functional capacity, and hemodynamic response to exercise. However, ST-segment changes during exercise ECG testing provide no diagnostic information in patients with paced ventricular rhythm or underlying left bundle branch block (LBBB) (Choice C). Also, a paced ventricular rhythm produces false-positive perfusion defects on exercise radionuclide myocardial perfusion imaging (Choice D). In such patients, pharmacologic radionuclide imaging (with adenosine, dipyridamole, or regadenoson) is preferred for evaluation of suspected CHD.

(Choice A) Coronary angiography is a reasonable alternate test in patients with a high probability of CHD (greater than 90%). However, this patient has an intermediate probability of CHD and should be evaluated initially with a pharmacologic stress test.

(Choice B) In patients with paced ventricular rhythm, a resting echocardiogram shows paradoxical septal motion due to early activation of the right ventricle. These findings can become more pronounced with exercise and lead to false-positive abnormalities.

Educational objective:
Pharmacologic radionuclide perfusion imaging should be performed to evaluate suspected coronary heart disease in patients with paced ventricular rhythm or left bundle branch block.

stem:
A 49-year-old woman comes to the office to discuss her risk of heart disease. Her husband recently died of an acute myocardial infarction, and she says, "I need to take care of myself so I can be there for my kids." The patient's medical history is unremarkable and she takes no medications. Her mother died of dementia at age 76, and her father died of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease at age 68. She has a 30-pack-year smoking history but quit after her husband's heart attack, and she drinks a can of beer every day. The patient has a sedentary occupation and does not engage in regular exercise. Blood pressure is 129/79 mm Hg and pulse is 80/min. BMI is 32 kg/m². Physical examination shows central obesity but is otherwise unremarkable.

Laboratory results are as follows:

Fasting lipid panel
Total cholesterol 196 mg/dL
HDL 42 mg/dL
LDL (calculated) 121 mg/dL
Triglycerides 166 mg/dL
Glucose 108 mg/dL

In addition to providing guidance on increasing physical activity, which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation to reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease in this patient?
choice_a: Add an antioxidant vitamin supplement to reduce the risk of coronary events
choice_b: Eliminate alcohol intake to reduce the risk of heart failure
choice_c: Initiate a low-carbohydrate diet to facilitate weight loss
choice_d: Initiate a Mediterranean-style diet to reduce the risk of cardiovascular mortality
choice_e: Restrict sodium intake to 1,500 mg/day to reduce the risk of stroke
explanation:
This patient has quit smoking, which, if sustained, is associated with a reduced risk of heart disease. However, she also has mild obesity, elevated blood pressure, hyperglycemia, and suboptimal lipid values, all of which are likely to worsen with age and increase her cardiovascular risk. These risk factors do not require medication at this time, but the patient would benefit from changes in lifestyle to address them now. The Mediterranean-style diet emphasizes plant-based foods (eg, fruits, vegetables, whole grains, nuts), olive oil (in place of butter), fish and poultry (in place of red meat), and moderate salt intake. Studies have found reductions in the risk of cardiac events and cardiovascular mortality with the Mediterranean diet compared with a conventional diet. Alternately, the similar Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension (DASH) diet has been shown to lower blood pressure and can reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease. Either of these dietary interventions would be appropriate for this patient.

(Choice A) Diets high in antioxidant-containing foods (eg, DASH diet, Mediterranean diet) are associated with a lower risk of coronary events. However, randomized trials of antioxidant supplements have consistently shown no benefit in preventing coronary events.

(Choice B) Heavy alcohol intake (>4 drinks/day for men, >2 drinks/day for women) is associated with an increased risk of heart failure. However, this patient's moderate alcohol intake has minimal impact on her risk of heart failure and is associated with a slightly reduced overall cardiovascular risk.

(Choice C) Both low-fat and low-carbohydrate diets are effective for weight loss, but evidence for reduced cardiac risk is weak. Patients who adhere to either the DASH diet or the Mediterranean diet frequently lose weight, and these programs are likely more effective for reducing cardiac risk.

(Choice E) A moderate reduction in sodium intake may be helpful for some patients. However a very-low sodium diet (eg, <1,500 mg/day) is unlikely to benefit most individuals, is difficult to sustain, and is generally advised only for patients with uncontrolled hypertension.

Educational objective:
Lifestyle interventions that can reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease include regular physical exercise, a Mediterranean-style diet, the Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension (DASH) diet, smoking cessation, and moderate but not excessive alcohol intake.

stem: A 20-year-old man comes to the office for a sports physical. The patient has played varsity basketball since high school. He has had no chest pain, shortness of breath, palpitations, or fainting spells. He has no medical history and takes no medications. There is no family history of sudden death. Blood pressure is 115/75 mm Hg, pulse is 56/min, and BMI is 22 kg/m². The patient is in no distress. The apical precordial impulse is hyperdynamic. There is a normal S1 and S2, and an S4 is heard. He has a 2/6 systolic murmur at the left sternal border that increases with Valsalva maneuver. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The abdomen is soft and nondistended. Peripheral pulses demonstrate a rapid upstroke followed by a decline and secondary rise. Tranthoracic echocardiogram reveals interventricular septal thickness of 1.8 cm (normal: <1.1 cm) and posterior left ventricular wall thickness of 0.9 cm (normal: <1.1 cm). Left ventricular ejection fraction is 75%. At rest, there is no left ventricular outflow gradient; however, Valsalva maneuver generates a gradient of 30 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation for this patient?
explanation:
This patient's presentation is consistent with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM), defined as left ventricular wall thickness ≥15 mm (1.5 cm) (at any location) in the absence of other potential causes (eg, hypertension, valvular heart disease). Patients with HCM may remain asymptomatic, or they may develop dyspnea, orthopnea, palpitations, chest pain, dizziness, or syncope. Exertional myocardial ischemia can lead to sustained ventricular arrhythmia and sudden cardiac death (SCD); HCM is the most common cause of SCD in young athletes. To lower the risk of SCD, patients with probable or definite HCM should not participate in high-intensity competitive sports regardless of the presence of symptoms, degree of wall thickness or left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction, or prior treatment.

(Choice A) Alcohol septal ablation or surgical septal myectomy is indicated for HCM patients with severe LVOT obstruction (resting or Valsalva gradient >50 mm Hg) and heart failure symptoms that are refractory to optimal medical therapy. This patient is currently asymptomatic; therefore, these procedures are not indicated.

(Choice C) An implantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD) is generally indicated for primary prevention in patients with risk factors for SCD (eg, left ventricular wall thickness >30 mm, family history of SCD due to HCM) and for secondary prevention in patients who survive an episode of sustained ventricular arrhythmia.

(Choice D) Medical therapy with negative inotropic agents (eg, beta blockers, nondihydropyridine calcium channel blockers, disopyramide) is recommended in patients with LVOT obstruction and symptoms of heart failure. It is not currently indicated in this asymptomatic patient.

(Choice E) Dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (eg, amlodipine, nifedipine) as well as other vasodilators (eg, ACE inhibitors) and diuretics should be avoided in patients with HCM as they decrease afterload and can worsen LVOT obstruction and symptoms.

Educational objective:
Patients with probable or definite hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, the most common cause of sudden cardiac death (SCD) in young athletes, should be instructed to avoid competitive sports or high-intensity physical activity.

stem: A 32-year-old paramedic comes to the office for a routine health maintenance examination. He has had headaches for the past several months as well as episodes of nosebleeds. He has no other medical problems. The patient does not use tobacco or illicit drugs but drinks 1 or 2 cans of beer daily. He has no family history of heart failure or sudden death. Temperature is 36.1 C (97 F); blood pressure is 188/96 mm Hg in the right arm, 184/94 mm Hg in the left arm, and 114/76 mm Hg in the right leg; pulse is 68/min, and respirations are 14/min. Height is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in). Examination reveals no audible carotid bruits. There is a 2/6 mid-systolic murmur heard at the left sternal border as well as a continuous "rumbling" sound heard in the back over the interscapular area. Diagnostic testing is most likely to demonstrate which of the following findings?
explanation:
This patient most likely has secondary hypertension due to coarctation of the aorta (CoA). A congenital narrowing of the descending aorta leads to proximal hypertension and decreased blood flow to the lower extremities. Asymptomatic hypertension of the upper body is the most common adult presentation, but patients can have headaches, epistaxis, lower extremity claudication, or symptoms of heart failure. On physical examination, brachial-femoral pulse delay strongly suggests the diagnosis. In addition, patients frequently have a continuous murmur, due to blood flow through collateral vessels (eg, intercostal arteries), that is best heard at the posterior interscapular area. An accompanying systolic murmur in a patient with CoA is typically the result of a coexisting cardiac lesion. Congenital bicuspid aortic valve is the most common defect associated with CoA (in approximately 40% of cases) and can be identified by echocardiography. Other commonly associated defects include ventricular septal defect, patent ductus arteriosus, and subvalvular or supravalvular aortic stenosis.

(Choice A) Atrial septal defect (primum type) is seen in patients with Down syndrome but is not associated with CoA.

(Choice C) Pulmonic stenosis is seen in association with tetralogy of Fallot and congenital rubella syndrome but does not have a significant association with CoA.

(Choice D) Right ventricular dysplasia is characterized by a combination of regional or global right ventricular abnormalities, characteristic fibrofatty changes on tissue biopsy, arrhythmias, and a family history of sudden death, but it is not associated with CoA.

(Choice E) Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome is seen in up to 20% of patients with Ebstein anomaly of the tricuspid valve; however, it is not associated with CoA.

Educational objective:
Coarctation of the aorta is a congenital narrowing of the descending aorta that causes upper body hypertension and may lead to lower body claudication. It is associated with several other congenital cardiac defects, with bicuspid aortic valve being the most common.

stem: A 60-year-old man comes to the office for presurgical evaluation before right-sided total knee replacement. He has pain and limited mobility due to severe knee osteoarthritis, and has gained 4.5 kg (10 lb) over the last 6 months due to decreased physical activity. Other medical problems include coronary artery disease, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. Four months ago, the patient underwent sirolimus-eluting stent implantation into the left anterior descending artery due to angina. Current medications are low-dose aspirin, prasugrel, metoprolol, valsartan, and rosuvastatin. ECG shows sinus rhythm with no pathologic Q waves or ST-segment abnormalities. Echocardiogram shows normal left ventricular systolic function and no wall motion abnormalities. Which of the following is the best recommendation for this patient before surgery?
explanation:
Dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) with aspirin and a P2Y12 inhibitor (eg, clopidogrel, prasugrel, ticagrelor) is recommended after intracoronary stent implantation to prevent stent thrombosis and subsequent myocardial infarction. Current guidelines recommend uninterrupted DAPT for at least 6-12 months after stent implantation to allow adequate endothelialization of the stent material. After that time, aspirin should be continued indefinitely. Whenever possible, elective noncardiac surgery should be postponed until at least 6 months after stent placement (or 1 month after bare-metal stent placement). If surgery cannot be delayed, DAPT (or at least aspirin alone) should be continued throughout the perioperative period to minimize the risk of catastrophic stent thrombosis. However, both drugs may need to be discontinued in patients undergoing surgery in which perioperative bleeding may cause significant morbidity, such as neurosurgery (Choice D).

(Choices A and C) This patient had DES placement 4 months ago and needs DAPT with aspirin and prasugrel for a minimum of 2 more months. Whenever possible, elective surgery should be postponed until the minimum recommended duration of DAPT is completed.

(Choice B) Continuing both aspirin and prasugrel increases the risk of perioperative bleeding; delaying surgery is preferred.

Educational objective:
Current guidelines recommend uninterrupted dual antiplatelet therapy with aspirin and a P2Y12 inhibitor (eg, clopidogrel, prasugrel, ticagrelor) for at least 6-12 months after intracoronary stent placement. Whenever possible, elective noncardiac surgery should be postponed until the minimum recommended duration of dual antiplatelet therapy is completed.

stem: A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician for follow-up of hypertension. When the patient was seen in the office two weeks ago, her blood pressure was 145/95 mm Hg initially and 140/92 mm Hg after recheck. Since then, she had her blood pressure taken three times at a nearby pharmacy, with readings averaging 120/80 mm Hg. The patient has no symptoms and feels "pretty healthy." She takes no medications. The patient's father has hypertension and coronary artery disease, which required coronary artery bypass grafting. Her mother has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. The patient regularly salts her food before tasting it. She drinks alcohol socially and does not use tobacco or illicit drugs. The patient works as an information technology consultant and exercises moderately three times a week. Blood pressure during this visit is 149/94 mm Hg initially and 138/94 mm Hg after 20 minutes. BMI is 28 kg/m². The ocular fundi appear normal. Physical examination is unremarkable. A complete blood count, urinalysis, and comprehensive metabolic panel are normal. Serum creatinine is 0.9 mg/dL. ECG shows normal sinus rhythm and T wave inversion in leads V1 and V2. Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient's blood pressure?
choice_b: Obtain echocardiogram to evaluate for left ventricular hypertrophy
choice_d: Schedule repeat office blood pressure checks
explanation:
This patient has elevated blood pressure in the physician's office and normal blood pressure outside the office, consistent with "white coat" hypertension. In such patients, 24-hour ambulatory blood pressure monitoring (ABPM) is indicated to more fully characterize the blood pressure pattern. ABPM measures and records pulse and blood pressure at 15- to 20-minute intervals during the day and at 30- to 60-minute intervals at night. ABPM more closely predicts future cardiovascular events and all-cause mortality than either physician's office or home blood pressure measurements. If ABPM results are normal and the patient has no evidence of end-organ damage, antihypertensive therapy may be deferred (Choice E). However, patients with white coat hypertension have an increased risk of developing sustained hypertension and warrant close long-term follow-up.

(Choice A) In addition to hypertension, pheochromocytoma also causes episodic palpitations, tremor, and diaphoresis. Pheochromocytoma is a rare disorder, and this patient's lack of symptoms makes it even less likely. Additional evaluation could be considered if episodic, severe hypertension is noted on ABPM.

(Choice B) Echocardiography is not necessary for routine evaluation of hypertension in asymptomatic patients. T wave inversion in only the right precordial leads is usually a normal finding and does not indicate left ventricular dysfunction or hypertensive heart disease.

(Choice D) Initial elevations in blood pressure taken during office visits often decline on subsequent checks, possibly due to increased patient comfort or statistical regression to the mean. However, this patient has mild but persistent office blood pressure elevations, and ABPM can more readily differentiate white coat hypertension from sustained hypertension.

Educational objective:
"White coat" hypertension refers to elevated blood pressure in the physician's office with normal blood pressure readings elsewhere. In such patients, 24-hour ambulatory blood pressure monitoring can more fully characterize the blood pressure pattern and is a better predictor of future cardiovascular events and all-cause mortality than are office or home blood pressure measurements.

stem: A 26-year-old man comes to the physician for a pre-employment physical evaluation. He has no known medical problems. The patient weighs 65 kg (143.3 lb) and is 190.5 cm (6' 3") tall. There is a faint early diastolic murmur best heard in the second right intercostal space. He has mild scoliosis. Physical examination findings in the extremities show positive wrist (thumb overlaps other fingers when wrapped around the contralateral wrist) and thumb (entire distal phalanx protrudes beyond the ulnar border of a clenched fist) signs. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
explanation:
Aortic regurgitation (early diastolic murmur at the second right intercostal space) in association with long extremities and scoliosis are suggestive of Marfan syndrome (MFS) with aortic root dilation. MFS is an autosomal dominant disorder that causes abnormalities in the skeleton, eyes (lens dislocation), and cardiovascular system. This patient also has positive wrist and thumb signs due to long slender fingers (arachnodactyly). Aortic root dilation can be found in approximately 50% of children and 60%-80% of adults with MFS. Aortic dissection is the cause of death in 30%-45% of patients, followed by heart failure. Transthoracic echocardiography is recommended at the initial diagnosis and at routine intervals for close monitoring of the aortic root and ascending aorta. Elective operation is recommended for aortic root diameter ≥50 mm to reduce the risk of aortic dissection or rupture.

(Choice A) Antinuclear antibody testing is used for the diagnosis of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and other autoimmune diseases. There is no association with MFS.

(Choice B) Chromosomal karyotype analysis is indicated for diagnosis of Klinefelter syndrome (KS). KS is characterized by hypogonadism, gynecomastia, and learning disabilities. There are usually no cardiac abnormalities associated with KS.

(Choice C) Homocystinuria is an autosomal recessive disorder that presents with fair complexion, Marfanoid body habitus, developmental delays, and hypercoagulability. It is not associated with aortic root dilation.

(Choice D) Skin biopsy is not helpful for MFS diagnosis but may be performed in the evaluation of patients with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.

Educational objective:
Aortic root disease, leading to aneurysmal dilation and dissection, is a common complication of Marfan syndrome, and is the main cause of morbidity and mortality in these patients. Transthoracic echocardiogram is recommended at initial diagnosis and at regular follow-up intervals.

A 37-year-old school teacher comes to the physician for a preventive care appointment. She denies any current symptoms, and she has not seen a doctor for many years. She takes over-the-counter vitamin and calcium supplements. She does not smoke and she drinks alcohol only on social occasions. Her temperature is 37.2 C (99 F), blood pressure is 122/80 mm Hg, pulse is 84/min, and respirations are 14/min. Jugular venous pressure is normal. Cardiac auscultation reveals wide and fixed splitting of the second heart sound. There is a 2/6 mid-systolic ejection murmur heard best over the left second intercostal space. The remainder of her physical examination is unremarkable.

Which of the following would most likely be present on her electrocardiogram?
choice_a: Abnormal Q waves in the inferior leads
choice_e: Short PR interval and delta waves
explanation:
This patient has the classic physical examination findings of a large atrial septal defect (ASD) with a left-to-right shunt. Depending on the duration and the size of the shunt, ASD patients can develop a number of ECG abnormalities. The QRS complex can become slightly prolonged with a characteristic rSr' or rsR' configuration, causing an incomplete or complete right bundle branch block pattern on ECG. Other ECG changes include first degree AV block, right axis deviation, and P wave changes suggestive of right atrial enlargement.

(Choice A) Inferior Q waves can be seen in prior myocardial infarction and various cardiomyopathies but are not associated with ASD.

(Choice B) Electrical alternans refers to a cyclic beat-to-beat variation in the QRS axis and amplitude and is most frequently seen in patients with significant pericardial effusion.

(Choice C) Pulmonary hypertension and right ventricular hypertrophy can develop in patients with an unrecognized, large ASD. Left ventricular hypertrophy is not typically seen.

(Choice E) A short PR interval and delta waves are classically seen in patients with Wolf-Parkinson-White pattern.

Educational objective:
ECG abnormalities commonly seen in patients with an atrial septal defect include first degree AV block, right axis deviation, and incomplete or complete right bundle branch block.

stem: A 32-year-old white man is referred for evaluation of a murmur noted on a pre-employment physical. He has no specific complaints. He is physically active and runs 4-5 miles almost every day. His older brother died of presumed sudden cardiac arrest at age 37 years. On physical examination, there is a wide, fixed splitting of the second heart sound. A faint mid-systolic ejection murmur is heard best over the left second intercostal space. Otherwise, his physical examination is unremarkable. An echocardiogram confirms the presence of a large secundum atrial septal defect. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the murmur?
choice_a: Dilatation of the main pulmonary artery
choice_b: Increased flow through the pulmonic valve
choice_c: Increased flow through the tricuspid valve
choice_d: Prolapse of the anterior mitral leaflet
choice_e: Shunt flow through the atrial septal defect
explanation:
Patients with atrial septal defect (ASD) and moderate-to-large left-to-right shunt have increased flow through the pulmonic valve. This produces a mid-systolic ejection murmur resulting from increased flow across the pulmonic valve. Another characteristic finding is the presence of wide and fixed splitting of the second heart sound.

(Choice A) Dilatation of the pulmonary artery is associated with pulmonic regurgitation and a low-pitched diastolic murmur.

(Choice C) Patients with large ASD and significant left-to-right shunting have increased flow across the tricuspid valve that produces a mid-diastolic murmur that does not increase with inspiration.

(Choice D) Mitral valve prolapse produces a single or multiple clicks, followed by a late systolic murmur.

(Choice E) The low-velocity left-to-right shunt flow across the atrial septal defect produces no audible murmur.

Educational objective:
Atrial septal defect with moderate-to-large left-to-right shunt causes a mid-systolic ejection murmur due to increased flow through the pulmonic valve.

stem: A 42-year-old woman comes to the physician before undergoing tooth extraction. She recently saw a dentist for lower jaw pain and was told that she needs extraction of a left lower molar. She has a past history of rheumatic heart disease and had mitral valve replacement at 35 years of age with a mechanical valve. She moved to the United States from the Philippines 3 years ago. Her past medical history is otherwise unremarkable. She takes warfarin daily and has been taking amoxicillin for the past 7 days for presumed "tooth infection." Physical examination reveals crisp opening and closing clicks of a mechanical prosthetic mitral valve. No abnormal murmurs are heard. Her last INR was 2.6. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient?
choice_a: Continue warfarin and proceed with dental extraction
choice_b: Hold warfarin, give subcutaneous vitamin K, and proceed with dental extraction
choice_c: Hold warfarin until INR is <1.5, bridge with subcutaneous enoxaparin, and proceed with dental extraction
choice_d: Hold warfarin, wait until INR is <1.5, and proceed with dental extraction
choice_e: Hold warfarin, wait until INR is <2.0, and proceed with dental extraction
explanation:
In patients with a mechanical prosthetic valve undergoing elective surgery, the decision to continue or hold warfarin anticoagulation is based on the risk of systemic thromboembolism and the risk of post-procedure bleeding. The presence of a mechanical prosthetic mitral valve puts the patient at a high risk for systemic thromboembolism. In patients undergoing low risk surgical procedures, such as dental extraction, warfarin anticoagulation is associated with a minimal risk of serious bleeding and should be continued through the procedure.

(Choice B) Withholding warfarin and administration of subcutaneous vitamin K will lead to a subtherapeutic INR and expose the patient to the risk of systemic thromboembolism.

(Choice C) Holding warfarin and bridging therapy with subcutaneous enoxaparin is not indicated in this situation due to minimal bleeding risk.

(Choices D & E) Warfarin should not be held for dental extraction as it exposes the patient to an excessive and unnecessary risk of systemic thromboembolism from a mechanical prosthetic mitral valve.

Educational objective:
In patients undergoing low risk surgical procedures (e.g., dental extraction, excisional skin biopsy, cataract surgery), warfarin anticoagulation is associated with a minimal risk of serious bleeding and should be continued through the procedure.

stem: A 64-year-old man with diet-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus, ischemic cardiomyopathy, and systolic heart failure comes to the physician for follow-up. The patient has New York Heart Association functional class II symptoms and shows no signs of fluid overload. His daily medications include furosemide, carvedilol, lisinopril, atorvastatin, and low-dose aspirin. The patient's blood pressure is 155/90 mm Hg and pulse is 60/min. His potassium level is 4.2 mEq/L and serum creatinine level is 0.9 mg/dL. Adding losartan to this patient's current regimen is most likely to result in which of the following?
choice_a: Higher risk for heart failure-associated hospital admission
explanation:
Blockade of the renin-angiotensin system with ACE inhibitors or angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs) significantly improves cardiovascular outcomes and overall mortality in patients with congestive heart failure due to left ventricular systolic dysfunction. However, dual blockade with both ACE inhibitors and ARBs has not been shown to provide any significant improvement in cardiovascular or all-cause mortality compared to monotherapy alone (Choice C). In addition, dual therapy is associated with an increased risk for hyperkalemia (Choice E), symptomatic hypotension, and worsening renal function and therefore is not recommended.

(Choice A) While not improving mortality or total hospitalizations, dual blockade of the renin-angiotensin system with ACE inhibitors and ARBs is associated with a reduction in the risk of heart failure-associated hospital admission.

(Choice D) Dual therapy is not associated with any significant change in the risk of arrhythmia compared to monotherapy alone.

Educational objective:
Dual blockade of the renin-angiotensin system with both ACE inhibitors and ARBs does not provide any significant benefit to cardiovascular or all-cause mortality over ACE inhibitors alone. Dual therapy is associated with an increased risk for hyperkalemia, hypotension, and worsening renal function.
